books.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 1

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 1:1
verses.text: Book IV.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 1:2
verses.text: Chapter I.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 1:3
verses.text: —Concerning what followed the Resurrection.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 1:4
verses.text: After Christ was risen from the dead He laid aside all His passions, I mean His corruption or hunger or thirst or sleep or weariness or such like.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 1:5
verses.text: For, although He did taste food after the resurrection, yet He did not do so because it was a law of His nature (for He felt no hunger), but in the way of economy, in order that He might convince us of the reality of the resurrection, and that it was one and the same flesh which suffered and rose again.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 1:6
verses.text: But He laid aside none of the divisions of His nature, neither body nor spirit, but possesses both the body and the soul intelligent and reasonable, volitional and energetic, and in this wise He sits at the right hand of the Father, using His will both as God and as man in behalf of our salvation, energising in His divine capacity to provide for and maintain and govern all things, and remembering in His human capacity the time He spent on earth, while all the time He both sees and knows that He is adored by all rational creation.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 1:7
verses.text: For His Holy Spirit knows that He is one in substance with God the Word, and shares as Spirit of God and not simply as Spirit the worship accorded to Him.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 1:8
verses.text: Moreover, His ascent from earth to heaven, and again, His descent from heaven to earth, are manifestations of the energies of His circumscribed body.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 1:9
verses.text: For He shall so come again to you, saith he, in like manner as ye have seen Him go into Heaven.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 2

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 2:1
verses.text: Chapter II.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 2:2
verses.text: —Concerning the sitting at the right hand of the Father.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 2:3
verses.text: We hold, moreover, that Christ sits in the body at the right hand of God the Father, but we do not hold that the right hand of the Father is actual place.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 2:4
verses.text: For how could He that is uncircumscribed have a right hand limited by place? Right hands and left hands belong to what is circumscribed.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 2:5
verses.text: But we understand the right hand of the Father to be the glory and honour of the Godhead in which the Son of God, who existed as God before the ages, and is of like essence to the Father, and in the end became flesh, has a seat in the body, His flesh sharing in the glory.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 2:6
verses.text: For He along with His flesh is adored with one adoration by all creation.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 3

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 3:1
verses.text: Chapter III.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 3:2
verses.text: —In reply to those who say "If Christ has two natures, either ye do service to the creature in worshipping created nature, or ye say that there is one nature to be worshipped, and another not to be worshipped".

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 3:3
verses.text: Along with the Father and the Holy Spirit we worship the Son of God, Who was incorporeal before He took on humanity, and now in His own person is incarnate and has become man though still being also God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 3:4
verses.text: His flesh, then, in its own nature, if one were to make subtle mental distinctions between what is seen and what is thought, is not deserving of worship since it is created.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 3:5
verses.text: But as it is united with God the Word, it is worshipped on account of Him and in Him.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 3:6
verses.text: For just as the king deserves homage alike when un-robed and when robed, and just as the purple robe, considered simply as a purple robe, is trampled upon and tossed about, but after becoming the royal dress receives all honour and glory, and whoever dishonours it is generally condemned to death: and again, just as wood in itself is not of such a nature that it cannot be touched, but becomes so when fire is applied to it, and it becomes charcoal, and yet this is not because of its own nature, but because of the fire united to it, and the nature of the wood is not such as cannot be touched, but rather the charcoal or burning wood: so also the flesh, in its own nature, is not to be worshipped, but is worshipped in the incarnate God Word, not because of itself, but because of its union in subsistence with God the Word.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 3:7
verses.text: And we do not say that we worship mere flesh, but God's flesh, that is, God incarnate.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 4

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 4:1
verses.text: Chapter IV.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 4:2
verses.text: —Why it was the Son of God, and not the Father or the Spirit, that became man: and what having became man He achieved.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 4:3
verses.text: The Father is Father and not Son: the Son is Son and not Father: the Holy Spirit is Spirit and not Father or Son.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 4:4
verses.text: For the individuality is unchangeable.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 4:5
verses.text: How, indeed, could individuality continue to exist at all if it were ever changing and altering? Wherefore the Son of God became Son of Man in order that His individuality might endure.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 4:6
verses.text: For since He was the Son of God, He became Son of Man, being made flesh of the holy Virgin and not losing the individuality of Sonship.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 4:7
verses.text: Further, the Son of God became man, in order that He might again bestow on man that favour for the sake of which He created him.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 4:8
verses.text: For He created him after His own image, endowed with intellect and free-will, and after His own likeness, that is to say, perfect in all virtue so far as it is possible for man's nature to attain perfection.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 4:9
verses.text: For the following properties are, so to speak, marks of the divine nature: viz.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 4:10
verses.text: absence of care and distraction and guile, goodness, wisdom, justice, freedom from all vice.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 4:11
verses.text: So then, after He had placed man in communion with Himself (for having made him for incorruption, He led him up through communion with Himself to incorruption), and when moreover, through the transgression of the command we had confused and obliterated the marks of the divine image, and had become evil, we were stripped of our communion with God (for what communion hath light with darkness?): and having been shut out from life we became subject to the corruption of death: yea, since He gave us to share in the better part, and we did not keep it secure, He shares in the inferior part, I mean our own nature, in order that through Himself and in Himself He might renew that which was made after His image and likeness, and might teach us, too, the conduct of a virtuous life, making through Himself the way thither easy for us, and might by the communication of life deliver us from corruption, becoming Himself the firstfruits of our resurrection, and might renovate the useless and worn vessel calling us to the knowledge of God that He might redeem us from the tyranny of the devil, and might strengthen and teach us how to overthrow the tyrant through patience and humility.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 4:12
verses.text: The worship of demons then has ceased: creation has been sanctified by the divine blood: altars and temples of idols have been overthrown, the knowledge of God has been implanted in men's minds, the co-essential Trinity, the uncreate divinity, one true God, Creator and Lord of all receives men's service: virtues are cultivated, the hope of resurrection has been granted through the resurrection of Christ, the demons shudder at those men who of old were under their subjection.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 4:13
verses.text: And the marvel, indeed, is that all this has been successfully brought about through His cross and passion and death.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 4:14
verses.text: Throughout all the earth the Gospel of the knowledge of God has been preached; no wars or weapons or armies being used to rout the enemy, but only a few, naked, poor, illiterate, persecuted and tormented men, who with their lives in their hands, preached Him Who was crucified in the flesh and died, and who became victors over the wise and powerful.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 4:15
verses.text: For the omnipotent power of the Cross accompanied them.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 4:16
verses.text: Death itself, which once was man's chiefest terror, has been overthrown, and now that which was once the object of hate and loathing is preferred to life.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 4:17
verses.text: These are the achievements of Christ's presence: these are the tokens of His power.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 4:18
verses.text: For it was not one people that He saved, as when through Moses He divided the sea and delivered Israel out of Egypt and the bondage of Pharaoh; nay, rather He rescued all mankind from the corruption of death and the bitter tyranny of sin: not leading them by force to virtue, not overwhelming them with earth or burning them with fire, or ordering the sinners to be stoned, but persuading men by gentleness and long-suffering to choose virtue and vie with one another, and find pleasure in the struggle to attain it.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 4:19
verses.text: For, formerly, it was sinners who were persecuted, and yet they clung all the closer to sin, and sin was looked upon by them as their God: but now for the sake of piety and virtue men choose persecutions and crucifixions and death.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 4:20
verses.text: Hail! O Christ, the Word and Wisdom and Power of God, and God omnipotent! What can we helpless ones give Thee in return for all these good gifts? For all are Thine, and Thou askest naught from us save our salvation, Thou Who Thyself art the Giver of this, and yet art grateful to those who receive it, through Thy unspeakable goodness.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 4:21
verses.text: Thanks be to Thee Who gave us life, and granted us the grace of a happy life, and restored us to that, when we had gone astray, through Thy unspeakable condescension.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 5

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 5:1
verses.text: Chapter V.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 5:2
verses.text: —In reply to those who ask if Christ's subsistence is create or uncreate.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 5:3
verses.text: The subsistence of God the Word before the Incarnation was simple and uncompound, and incorporeal and uncreate: but after it became flesh, it became also the subsistence of the flesh, and became compounded of divinity which it always possessed, and of flesh which it had assumed: and it bears the properties of the two natures, being made known in two natures: so that the one same subsistence is both uncreate in divinity and create in humanity, visible and invisible.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 5:4
verses.text: For otherwise we are compelled either to divide the one Christ and speak of two subsistences, or to deny the distinction between the natures and thus introduce change and confusion.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 6

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 6:1
verses.text: Chapter VI.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 6:2
verses.text: —Concerning the question, when Christ was called.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 6:3
verses.text: The mind was not united with God the Word, as some falsely assert, before the Incarnation by the Virgin and from that time called Christ.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 6:4
verses.text: That is the absurd nonsense of Origen who lays down the doctrine of the priority of the existence of souls.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 6:5
verses.text: But we hold that the Son and Word of God became Christ after He had dwelt in the womb of His holy ever-virgin Mother, and became flesh without change, and that the flesh was anointed with divinity.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 6:6
verses.text: For this is the anointing of humanity, as Gregory the Theologian says.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 6:7
verses.text: And here are the words of the most holy Cyril of Alexandria which he wrote to the Emperor Theodosius: "For I indeed hold that one ought to give the name Jesus Christ neither to the Word that is of God if He is without humanity, nor yet to the temple born of woman if it is not united with the Word.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 6:8
verses.text: For the Word that is of God is understood to be Christ when united with humanity in ineffable manner in the union of the oeconomy".

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 6:9
verses.text: And again, he writes to the Empresses thus: "Some hold that the name 'Christ' is rightly given to the Word that is begotten of God the Father, to Him alone, and regarded separately by Himself.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 6:10
verses.text: But we have not been taught so to think and speak.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 6:11
verses.text: For when the Word became flesh, then it was, we say, that He was called Christ Jesus.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 6:12
verses.text: For since He was anointed with the oil of gladness, that is the Spirit, by Him Who is God and Father, He is for this reason called Christ.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 6:13
verses.text: But that the anointing was an act that concerned Him as man could be doubted by no one who is accustomed to think rightly".

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 6:14
verses.text: Moreover, the celebrated Athanasius says this in his discourse "Concerning the Saving Manifestation:" "The God Who was before the sojourn in the flesh was not man, but God in God, being invisible and without passion, but when He became man, He received in addition the name of Christ because of the flesh, since, indeed, passion and death follow in the train of this name".

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 6:15
verses.text: And although the holy Scripture says, Therefore God, thy God, hath anointed thee with the oil of gladness, it is to be observed that the holy Scripture often uses the past tense instead of the future, as for example here: Thereafter He was seen upon the earth and dwelt among men.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 6:16
verses.text: For as yet God was not seen nor did He dwell among men when this was said.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 6:17
verses.text: And here again: By the rivers of Babylon, there we sat down; yea wept.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 6:18
verses.text: For as yet these things had not come to pass.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 7

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 7:1
verses.text: Chapter VII.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 7:2
verses.text: —In answer to those who enquire whether the holy Mother of God bore two natures, and whether two natures hung upon the Cross.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 7:3
verses.text: ἀγένητον and γενητόν, written with one 'ν' and meaning uncreated and created, refer to nature: but ἀγέννητον and γεννητόν, that is to say, unbegotten and begotten, as the double 'ν' indicates, refer not to nature but to subsistence.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 7:4
verses.text: The divine nature then is ἀγένητος, that is to say, uncreate, but all things that come after the divine nature are γένητα, that is, created.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 7:5
verses.text: In the divine and uncreated nature, therefore, the property of being ἀγέννητον or unbegotten is contemplated in the Father (for He was not begotten), that of being γέννητον or begotten in the Son (for He has been eternally begotten of the Father), and that of procession in the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 7:6
verses.text: Moreover of each species of living creatures, the first members were ἀγέννητα but not ἀγένητα: for they were brought into being by their Maker, but were not the offspring of creatures like themselves.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 7:7
verses.text: For γένεσις is creation, while γέννησις or begetting is in the case of God the origin of a co-essential Son arising from the Father alone, and in the case of bodies, the origin of a co-essential subsistence arising from the contact of male and female.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 7:8
verses.text: And thus we perceive that begetting refers not to nature but to subsistence.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 7:9
verses.text: For if it did refer to nature, τὸ γέννητον and το ἀγέννητον, i-e: the properties of being begotten and unbegotten, could not be contemplated in one and the same nature.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 7:10
verses.text: Accordingly the holy Mother of God bore a subsistence revealed in two natures; being begotten on the one hand, by reason of its divinity, of the Father timelessly, and, at last, on the other hand, being incarnated of her in time and born in the flesh.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 7:11
verses.text: But if our interrogators should hint that He Who is begotten of the holy Mother of God is two natures, we reply, "Yea! He is two natures: for He is in His own person God and man.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 7:12
verses.text: And the same is to be said concerning the crucifixion and resurrection and ascension.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 7:13
verses.text: For these refer not to nature but to subsistence.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 7:14
verses.text: Christ then, since He is in two natures, suffered and was crucified in the nature that was subject to passion.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 7:15
verses.text: For it was in the flesh and not in His divinity that He hung upon the Cross.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 7:16
verses.text: Otherwise, let them answer us, when we ask if two natures died.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 7:17
verses.text: No, we shall say.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 7:18
verses.text: And so two natures were not crucified but Christ was begotten, that is to say, the divine Word having become man was begotten in the flesh, was crucified in the flesh, suffered in the flesh, while His divinity continued to be impassible".

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 8

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 8:1
verses.text: Chapter VIII.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 8:2
verses.text: —How the Only-begotten Son of God is called first-born.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 8:3
verses.text: He who is first begotten is called first-born, whether he is only-begotten or the first of a number of brothers.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 8:4
verses.text: If then the Son of God was called first-born, but was not called Only-begotten, we could imagine that He was the first-born of creatures, as being a creature.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 8:5
verses.text: But since He is called both first-born and Only-begotten, both senses must be preserved in His case.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 8:6
verses.text: We say that He is first-born of all creation since both He Himself is of God and creation is of God, but as He Himself is born alone and timelessly of the essence of God the Father, He may with reason be called Only-begotten Son, first-born and not first-created.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 8:7
verses.text: For the creation was not brought into being out of the essence of the Father, but by His will out of nothing.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 8:8
verses.text: And He is called First-born among many brethren, for although being Only-begotten, He was also born of a mother.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 8:9
verses.text: Since, indeed, He participated just as we ourselves do in blood and flesh and became man, while we too through Him became sons of God, being adopted through the baptism, He Who is by nature Son of God became first-born amongst us who were made by adoption and grace sons of God, and stand to Him in the relation of brothers.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 8:10
verses.text: Wherefore He said, I ascend unto My Father and your Father.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 8:11
verses.text: He did not say "our Father," but "My Father," clearly in the sense of Father by nature, and "your Father," in the sense of Father by grace.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 8:12
verses.text: And "My God and your God".

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 8:13
verses.text: He did not say "our God," but "My God:" and if you distinguish with subtle thought that which is seen from that which is thought, also "your God," as Maker and Lord.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:1
verses.text: Chapter IX.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:2
verses.text: —Concerning Faith and Baptism.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:3
verses.text: We confess one baptism for the remission of sins and for life eternal.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:4
verses.text: For baptism declares the Lord's death.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:5
verses.text: We are indeed "buried with the Lord through baptism," as saith the divine Apostle.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:6
verses.text: So then, as our Lord died once for all, we also must be baptized once for all, and baptized according to the Word of the Lord, In the Name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit, being taught the confession in Father, Son, and Holy Spirit.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:7
verses.text: Those, then, who, after having been baptized into Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, and having been taught that there is one divine nature in three subsistences, are rebaptized, these, as the divine Apostle says, crucify the Christ afresh.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:8
verses.text: For it is impossible, he saith, for those who were once enlightened, &c.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:9
verses.text: , to renew them again unto repentance: seeing they crucify to themselves the Christ afresh, and put Him to an open shame.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:10
verses.text: But those who were not baptized into the Holy Trinity, these must be baptized again.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:11
verses.text: For although the divine Apostle says: Into Christ and into His death were we baptized, he does not mean that the invocation of baptism must be in these words, but that baptism is an image of the death of Christ.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:12
verses.text: For by the three immersions, baptism signifies the three days of our Lord's entombment.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:13
verses.text: The baptism then into Christ means that believers are baptized into Him.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:14
verses.text: We could not believe in Christ if we were not taught confession in Father, Son, and Holy Spirit.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:15
verses.text: For Christ is the Son of the Living God, Whom the Father anointed with the Holy Spirit: in the words of the divine David, Therefore God, thy God, hath anointed thee with the oil of gladness above thy fellows.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:16
verses.text: And Isaiah also speaking in the person of the Lord says, The Spirit of the Lord is upon me because He hath anointed me.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:17
verses.text: Christ, however, taught His own disciples the invocation and said, Baptizing them in the Name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:18
verses.text: For since Christ made us for incorruption , and we transgressed His saving command, He condemned us to the corruption of death in order that that which is evil should not be immortal, and when in His compassion He stooped to His servants and became like us, He redeemed us from corruption through His own passion.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:19
verses.text: He caused the fountain of remission to well forth for us out of His holy and immaculate side, water for our regeneration, and the washing away of sin and corruption; and blood to drink as the hostage of life eternal.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:20
verses.text: And He laid on us the command to be born again of water and of the Spirit, through prayer and invocation, the Holy Spirit drawing nigh unto the water.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:21
verses.text: For since man's nature is twofold, consisting of soul and body, He bestowed on us a twofold purification, of water and of the Spirit: the Spirit renewing that part in us which is after His image and likeness, and the water by the grace of the Spirit cleansing the body from sin and delivering it from corruption, the water indeed expressing the image of death, but the Spirit affording the earnest of life.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:22
verses.text: For from the beginning the Spirit of God moved upon the face of the waters, and anew the Scripture witnesseth that water has the power of purification.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:23
verses.text: In the time of Noah God washed away the sin of the world by water.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:24
verses.text: By water every impure person is purified, according to the law, even the very garments being washed with water.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:25
verses.text: Elias shewed forth the grace of the Spirit mingled with the water when he burned the holocaust by pouring on water.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:26
verses.text: And almost everything is purified by water according to the law: for the things of sight are symbols of the things of thought.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:27
verses.text: The regeneration, however, takes place in the spirit: for faith has the power of making us sons (of God), creatures as we are, by the Spirit, and of leading us into our original blessedness.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:28
verses.text: The remission of sins, therefore, is granted alike to all through baptism: but the grace of the Spirit is proportional to the faith and previous purification.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:29
verses.text: Now, indeed, we receive the firstfruits of the Holy Spirit through baptism, and the second birth is for us the beginning and seal and security and illumination of another life.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:30
verses.text: It behoves us, then, with all our strength to steadfastly keep ourselves pure from filthy works, that we may not, like the dog returning to his vomit, make ourselves again the slaves of sin.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:31
verses.text: For faith apart from works is dead, and so likewise are works apart from faith.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:32
verses.text: For the true faith is attested by works.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:33
verses.text: Now we are baptized into the Holy Trinity because those things which are baptized have need of the Holy Trinity for their maintenance and continuance, and the three subsistences cannot be otherwise than present, the one with the other.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:34
verses.text: For the Holy Trinity is indivisible.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:35
verses.text: The first baptism was that of the flood for the eradication of sin.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:36
verses.text: The second was through the sea and the cloud: for the cloud is the symbol of the Spirit and the sea of the water.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:37
verses.text: The third baptism was that of the Law: for every impure person washed himself with water, and even washed his garments, and so entered into the camp.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:38
verses.text: The fourth was that of John, being preliminary and leading those who were baptized to repentance, that they might believe in Christ: I, indeed, he said, baptize you with water; but He that cometh after me, He will baptize you in the Holy Spirit and in fire.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:39
verses.text: Thus John's purification with water was preliminary to receiving the Spirit.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:40
verses.text: The fifth was the baptism of our Lord, whereby He Himself was baptized.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:41
verses.text: Now He is baptized not as Himself requiring purification but as making my purification His own, that He may break the heads of the dragons on the water, that He may wash away sin and bury all the old Adam in water, that He may sanctify the Baptist, that He may fulfil the Law, that He may reveal the mystery of the Trinity, that He may become the type and ensample to us of baptism.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:42
verses.text: But we, too, are baptized in the perfect baptism of our Lord, the baptism by water and the Spirit.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:43
verses.text: Moreover, Christ is said to baptize with fire: because in the form of flaming tongues He poured forth on His holy disciples the grace of the Spirit: as the Lord Himself says, John truly baptized with water: but ye shall be baptized with the Holy Spirit and with fire, not many days hence: or else it is because of the baptism of future fire wherewith we are to be chastized.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:44
verses.text: The sixth is that by repentance and tears, which baptism is truly grievous.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:45
verses.text: The seventh is baptism by blood and martyrdom, which baptism Christ Himself underwent in our behalf, He Who was too august and blessed to be defiled with any later stains.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:46
verses.text: The eighth is the last, which is not saving, but which destroys evil: for evil and sin no longer have sway: yet it punishes without end.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:47
verses.text: Further, the Holy Spirit descended in bodily form as a dove, indicating the firstfruits of our baptism and honouring the body: since even this, that is the body, was God by the deification; and besides the dove was wont formerly to announce the cessation of the flood.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:48
verses.text: But to the holy Apostles He came down in the form of fire: for He is God, and God is a consuming fire.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:49
verses.text: Olive oil is employed in baptism as a significant of our anointing, and as making us anointed, and as announcing to us through the Holy Spirit God's pity: for it was the fruit of the olive that the dove brought to those who were saved from the flood.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:50
verses.text: John was baptized, putting his hand upon the divine head of his Master, and with his own blood.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:51
verses.text: It does not behove us to delay baptism when the faith of those coming forward is testified to by their works.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 9:52
verses.text: For he that cometh forward deceitfully to baptism will receive condemnation rather than benefit.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 10

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 10:1
verses.text: Chapter X.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 10:2
verses.text: —Concerning Faith.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 10:3
verses.text: Moreover, faith is twofold.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 10:4
verses.text: For faith cometh by hearing.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 10:5
verses.text: For by hearing the divine Scriptures we believe in the teaching of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 10:6
verses.text: The same is perfected by all the things enjoined by Christ, believing in work, cultivating piety, and doing the commands of Him Who restored us.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 10:7
verses.text: For he that believeth not according to the tradition of the Catholic Church, or who hath intercourse with the devil through strange works, is an unbeliever.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 10:8
verses.text: But again, faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not seen, or undoubting and unambiguous hope alike of what God hath promised us and of the good issue of our prayers.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 10:9
verses.text: The first, therefore, belongs to our will, while the second is of the gifts of the Spirit.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 10:10
verses.text: Further, observe that by baptism we cut off all the covering which we have worn since birth, that is to say, sin, and become spiritual Israelites and God's people.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:1
verses.text: Chapter XI.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:2
verses.text: —Concerning the Cross and here further concerning Faith.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:3
verses.text: The word 'Cross' is foolishness to those that perish, but to us who are saved it is the power of God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:4
verses.text: For he that is spiritual judgeth all things, but the natural man receiveth not the things of the Spirit.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:5
verses.text: For it is foolishness to those who do not receive in faith and who do not consider God's goodness and omnipotence, but search out divine things with human and natural reasonings.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:6
verses.text: For all the things that are of God are above nature and reason and conception.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:7
verses.text: For should any one consider how and for what purpose God brought all things out of nothing and into being, and aim at arriving at that by natural reasonings, he fails to comprehend it.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:8
verses.text: For knowledge of this kind belongs to spirits and demons.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:9
verses.text: But if any one, under the guidance of faith, should consider the divine goodness and omnipotence and truth and wisdom and justice, he will find all things smooth and even, and the way straight.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:10
verses.text: But without faith it is impossible to be saved.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:11
verses.text: For it is by faith that all things, both human and spiritual, are sustained.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:12
verses.text: For without faith neither does the farmer cut his furrow, nor does the merchant commit his life to the raging waves of the sea on a small piece of wood, nor are marriages contracted nor any other step in life taken.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:13
verses.text: By faith we consider that all things were brought out of nothing into being by God's power.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:14
verses.text: And we direct all things, both divine and human, by faith.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:15
verses.text: Further, faith is assent free from all meddlesome inquisitiveness.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:16
verses.text: Every action, therefore, and performance of miracles by Christ are most great and divine and marvellous: but the most marvellous of all is His precious Cross.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:17
verses.text: For no other thing has subdued death, expiated the sin of the first parent, despoiled Hades, bestowed the resurrection, granted the power to us of contemning the present and even death itself, prepared the return to our former blessedness, opened the gates of Paradise, given our nature a seat at the right hand of God, and made us the children and heirs of God, save the Cross of our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:18
verses.text: For by the Cross all things have been made right.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:19
verses.text: So many of us, the apostle says, as were baptized into Christ, were baptized into His death, and as many of you as have been baptized into Christ, have put on Christ.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:20
verses.text: Further Christ is the power of God and the wisdom of God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:21
verses.text: Lo! the death of Christ, that is, the Cross, clothed us with the enhypostatic wisdom and power of God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:22
verses.text: And the power of God is the Word of the Cross, either because God's might, that is, the victory over death, has been revealed to us by it, or because, just as the four extremities of the Cross are held fast and bound together by the bolt in the middle, so also by God's power the height and the depth, the length and the breadth, that is, every creature visible and invisible, is maintained.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:23
verses.text: This was given to us as a sign on our forehead, just as the circumcision was given to Israel: for by it we believers are separated and distinguished from unbelievers.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:24
verses.text: This is the shield and weapon against, and trophy over, the devil.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:25
verses.text: This is the seal that the destroyer may not touch you, as saith the Scripture.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:26
verses.text: This is the resurrection of those lying in death, the support of the standing, the staff of the weak, the rod of the flock, the safe conduct of the earnest, the perfection of those that press forwards, the salvation of soul and body, the aversion of all things evil, the patron of all things good, the taking away of sin, the plant of resurrection, the tree of eternal life.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:27
verses.text: So, then, this same truly precious and august tree, on which Christ hath offered Himself as a sacrifice for our sakes, is to be worshipped as sanctified by contact with His holy body and blood; likewise the nails, the spear, the clothes, His sacred tabernacles which are the manger, the cave, Golgotha, which bringeth salvation, the tomb which giveth life, Sion, the chief stronghold of the churches and the like, are to be worshipped.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:28
verses.text: In the words of David, the father of God, We shall go into His tabernacles, we shall worship at the place where His feet stood.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:29
verses.text: And that it is the Cross that is meant is made clear by what follows, Arise, O Lord, into Thy Rest.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:30
verses.text: For the resurrection comes after the Cross.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:31
verses.text: For if of those things which we love, house and couch and garment, are to be longed after, how much the rather should we long after that which belonged to God, our Saviour, by means of which we are in truth saved.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:32
verses.text: Moreover we worship even the image of the precious and life-giving Cross, although made of another tree, not honouring the tree (God forbid) but the image as a symbol of Christ.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:33
verses.text: For He said to His disciples, admonishing them, Then shall appear the sign of the Son of Man in Heaven, meaning the Cross.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:34
verses.text: And so also the angel of the resurrection said to the woman, Ye seek Jesus of Nazareth which was crucified.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:35
verses.text: And the Apostle said, We preach Christ crucified.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:36
verses.text: For there are many Christs and many Jesuses, but one crucified.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:37
verses.text: He does not say speared but crucified.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:38
verses.text: It behoves us, then, to worship the sign of Christ.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:39
verses.text: For wherever the sign may be, there also will He be.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:40
verses.text: But it does not behove us to worship the material of which the image of the Cross is composed, even though it be gold or precious stones, after it is destroyed, if that should happen.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:41
verses.text: Everything, therefore, that is dedicated to God we worship, conferring the adoration on Him.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:42
verses.text: The tree of life which was planted by God in Paradise pre-figured this precious Cross.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:43
verses.text: For since death was by a tree, it was fitting that life and resurrection should be bestowed by a tree.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:44
verses.text: Jacob, when He worshipped the top of Joseph's staff, was the first to image the Cross, and when he blessed his sons with crossed hands he made most clearly the sign of the cross.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:45
verses.text: Likewise also did Moses' rod, when it smote the sea in the figure of the cross and saved Israel, while it overwhelmed Pharaoh in the depths; likewise also the hands stretched out crosswise and routing Amalek; and the bitter water made sweet by a tree, and the rock rent and pouring forth streams of water, and the rod that meant for Aaron the dignity of the high priesthood: and the serpent lifted in triumph on a tree as though it were dead, the tree bringing salvation to those who in faith saw their enemy dead, just as Christ was nailed to the tree in the flesh of sin which yet knew no sin.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:46
verses.text: The mighty Moses cried, You will see your life hanging on the tree before your eyes, and Isaiah likewise, I have spread out my hands all the day unto a faithless and rebellious people.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 11:47
verses.text: But may we who worship this obtain a part in Christ the crucified, Amen.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 12

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 12:1
verses.text: Chapter XII.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 12:2
verses.text: —Concerning Worship towards the East.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 12:3
verses.text: It is not without reason or by chance that we worship towards the East.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 12:4
verses.text: But seeing that we are composed of a visible and an invisible nature, that is to say, of a nature partly of spirit and partly of sense, we render also a twofold worship to the Creator; just as we sing both with our spirit and our bodily lips, and are baptized with both water and Spirit, and are united with the Lord in a twofold manner, being sharers in the mysteries and in the grace of the Spirit.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 12:5
verses.text: Since, therefore, God is spiritual light, and Christ is called in the Scriptures Sun of Righteousness and Dayspring, the East is the direction that must be assigned to His worship.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 12:6
verses.text: For everything good must be assigned to Him from Whom every good thing arises.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 12:7
verses.text: Indeed the divine David also says, Sing unto God, ye kingdoms of the earth: O sing praises unto the Lord: to Him that rideth upon the Heavens of heavens towards the East.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 12:8
verses.text: Moreover the Scripture also says, And God planted a garden eastward in Eden; and there He put the man whom He had formed: and when he had transgressed His command He expelled him and made him to dwell over against the delights of Paradise, which clearly is the West.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 12:9
verses.text: So, then, we worship God seeking and striving after our old fatherland.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 12:10
verses.text: Moreover the tent of Moses had its veil and mercy seat towards the East.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 12:11
verses.text: Also the tribe of Judah as the most precious pitched their camp on the East.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 12:12
verses.text: Also in the celebrated temple of Solomon the Gate of the Lord was placed eastward.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 12:13
verses.text: Moreover Christ, when He hung on the Cross, had His face turned towards the West, and so we worship, striving after Him.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 12:14
verses.text: And when He was received again into Heaven He was borne towards the East, and thus His apostles worship Him, and thus He will come again in the way in which they beheld Him going towards Heaven; as the Lord Himself said, As the lightning cometh out of the East and shinetheven unto the West, so also shall the coming of the Son of Man be.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 12:15
verses.text: So, then, in expectation of His coming we worship towards the East.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 12:16
verses.text: But this tradition of the apostles is unwritten.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 12:17
verses.text: For much that has been handed down to us by tradition is unwritten.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:1
verses.text: Chapter XIII.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:2
verses.text: —Concerning the holy and immaculate Mysteries of the Lord.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:3
verses.text: God Who is good and altogether good and more than good, Who is goodness throughout, by reason of the exceeding riches of His goodness did not suffer Himself, that is His nature, only to be good, with no other to participate therein, but because of this He made first the spiritual and heavenly powers: next the visible and sensible universe: next man with his spiritual and sentient nature.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:4
verses.text: All things, therefore, which he made, share in His goodness in respect of their existence.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:5
verses.text: For He Himself is existence to all, since all things that are, are in Him, not only because it was He that brought them out of nothing into being, but because His energy preserves and maintains all that He made: and in especial the living creatures.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:6
verses.text: For both in that they exist and in that they enjoy life they share in His goodness.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:7
verses.text: But in truth those of them that have reason have a still greater share in that, both because of what has been already said and also because of the very reason which they possess.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:8
verses.text: For they are somehow more dearly akin to Him, even though He is incomparably higher than they.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:9
verses.text: Man, however, being endowed with reason and free will, received the power of continuous union with God through his own choice, if indeed he should abide in goodness, that is in obedience to his Maker.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:10
verses.text: Since, however, he transgressed the command of his Creator and became liable to death and corruption, the Creator and Maker of our race, because of His bowels of compassion, took on our likeness, becoming man in all things but without sin, and was united to our nature.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:11
verses.text: For since He bestowed on us His own image and His own spirit and we did not keep them safe, He took Himself a share in our poor and weak nature, in order that He might cleanse us and make us incorruptible, and establish us once more as partakers of His divinity.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:12
verses.text: For it was fitting that not only the first-fruits of our nature should partake in the higher good but every man who wished it, and that a second birth should take place and that the nourishment should be new and suitable to the birth and thus the measure of perfection be attained.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:13
verses.text: Through His birth, that is, His incarnation, and baptism and passion and resurrection, He delivered our nature from the sin of our first parent and death and corruption, and became the first-fruits of the resurrection, and made Himself the way and image and pattern, in order that we, too, following in His footsteps, may become by adoption what He is Himself by nature, sons and heirs of God and joint heirs with Him.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:14
verses.text: He gave us therefore, as I said, a second birth in order that, just as we who are born of Adam are in his image and are the heirs of the curse and corruption, so also being born of Him we may be in His likeness and heirs of His incorruption and blessing and glory.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:15
verses.text: Now seeing that this Adam is spiritual, it was meet that both the birth and likewise the food should be spiritual too, but since we are of a double and compound nature, it is meet that both the birth should be double and likewise the food compound.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:16
verses.text: We were therefore given a birth by water and Spirit: I mean, by the holy baptism: and the food is the very bread of life, our Lord Jesus Christ, Who came down from heaven.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:17
verses.text: For when He was about to take on Himself a voluntary death for our sakes, on the night on which He gave Himself up, He laid a new covenant on His holy disciples and apostles, and through them on all who believe on Him.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:18
verses.text: In the upper chamber, then, of holy and illustrious Sion, after He had eaten the ancient Passover with His disciples and had fulfilled the ancient covenant, He washed His disciples' feet in token of the holy baptism.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:19
verses.text: Then having broken bread He gave it to them saying, Take, eat, this is My body broken for you for the remission of sins.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:20
verses.text: Likewise also He took the cup of wine and water and gave it to them saying, Drink ye all of it: for this is My blood, the blood of the New Testament which is shed for you for the remission of sins.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:21
verses.text: This do ye in remembrance of Me.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:22
verses.text: For as often as ye eat this bread and drink this cup, ye do shew the death of the Son of man and confess His resurrection until He come.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:23
verses.text: If then the Word of God is quick and energising, and the Lord did all that He willed; if He said, Let there be light and there was light, let there be a firmament and there was a firmament; if the heavens were established by the Word of the Lord and all the host of them by the breath of His mouth; if the heaven and the earth, water and fire and air and the whole glory of these, and, in sooth, this most noble creature, man, were perfected by the Word of the Lord; if God the Word of His own will became man and the pure and undefiled blood of the holy and ever-virginal One made His flesh without the aid of seed, can He not then make the bread His body and the wine and water His blood? He said in the beginning, Let the earth bring forth grass, and even until this present day, when the rain comes it brings forth its proper fruits, urged on and strengthened by the divine command.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:24
verses.text: God said, This is My body, and This is My blood, and this do ye in remembrance of Me.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:25
verses.text: And so it is at His omnipotent command until He come: for it was in this sense that He said until He come: and the overshadowing power of the Holy Spirit becomes through the invocation the rain to this new tillage.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:26
verses.text: For just as God made all that He made by the energy of the Holy Spirit, so also now the energy of the Spirit performs those things that are supernatural and which it is not possible to comprehend unless by faith alone.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:27
verses.text: How shall this be, said the holy Virgin, seeing I know not a man? And the archangel Gabriel answered her: The Holy Spirit shall come upon thee, and the power of the Highest shall overshadow thee.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:28
verses.text: And now you ask, how the bread became Christ's body and the wine and water Christ's blood.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:29
verses.text: And I say unto thee, "The Holy Spirit is present and does those things which surpass reason and thought".

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:30
verses.text: Further, bread and wine are employed: for God knoweth man's infirmity: for in general man turns away discontentedly from what is not well-worn by custom: and so with His usual indulgence He performs His supernatural works through familiar objects: and just as, in the case of baptism, since it is man's custom to wash himself with water and anoint himself with oil, He connected the grace of the Spirit with the oil and the water and made it the water of regeneration, in like manner since it is man's custom to eat and to drink water and wine, He connected His divinity with these and made them His body and blood in order that we may rise to what is supernatural through what is familiar and natural.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:31
verses.text: The body which is born of the holy Virgin is in truth body united with divinity, not that the body which was received up into the heavens descends, but that the bread itself and the wine are changed into God's body and blood.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:32
verses.text: But if you enquire how this happens, it is enough for you to learn that it was through the Holy Spirit, just as the Lord took on Himself flesh that subsisted in Him and was born of the holy Mother of God through the Spirit.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:33
verses.text: And we know nothing further save that the Word of God is true and energises and is omnipotent, but the manner of this cannot be searched out.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:34
verses.text: But one can put it well thus, that just as in nature the bread by the eating and the wine and the water by the drinking are changed into the body and blood of the eater and drinker, and do not become a different body from the former one, so the bread of the table and the wine and water are supernaturally changed by the invocation and presence of the Holy Spirit into the body and blood of Christ, and are not two but one and the same.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:35
verses.text: Wherefore to those who partake worthily with faith, it is for the remission of sins and for life everlasting and for the safeguarding of soul and body; but to those who partake unworthily without faith, it is for chastisement and punishment, just as also the death of the Lord became to those who believe life and incorruption for the enjoyment of eternal blessedness, while to those who do not believe and to the murderers of the Lord it is for everlasting chastisement and punishment.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:36
verses.text: The bread and the wine are not merely figures of the body and blood of Christ (God forbid!) but the deified body of the Lord itself: for the Lord has said, "This is My body," not, this is a figure of My body: and "My blood," not, a figure of My blood.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:37
verses.text: And on a previous occasion He had said to the Jews, Except ye eat the flesh of the Son of Man and drink His blood, ye have no life in you.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:38
verses.text: For My flesh is meat indeed and My blood is drink indeed.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:39
verses.text: And again, He that eateth Me, shall live.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:40
verses.text: Wherefore with all fear and a pure conscience and certain faith let us draw near and it will assuredly be to us as we believe, doubting nothing.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:41
verses.text: Let us pay homage to it in all purity both of soul and body: for it is twofold.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:42
verses.text: Let us draw near to it with an ardent desire, and with our hands held in the form of the cross let us receive the body of the Crucified One: and let us apply our eyes and lips and brows and partake of the divine coal, in order that the fire of the longing, that is in us, with the additional heat derived from the coal may utterly consume our sins and illumine our hearts, and that we may be inflamed and deified by the participation in the divine fire.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:43
verses.text: Isaiah saw the coal.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:44
verses.text: But coal is not plain wood but wood united with fire: in like manner also the bread of the communion is not plain bread but bread united with divinity.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:45
verses.text: But a body which is united with divinity is not one nature, but has one nature belonging to the body and another belonging to the divinity that is united to it, so that the compound is not one nature but two.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:46
verses.text: With bread and wine Melchisedek, the priest of the most high God, received Abraham on his return from the slaughter of the Gentiles.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:47
verses.text: That table pre-imaged this mystical table, just as that priest was a type and image of Christ, the true high-priest.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:48
verses.text: For thou art a priest for ever after the order of Melchisedek.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:49
verses.text: Of this bread the show-bread was an image.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:50
verses.text: This surely is that pure and bloodless sacrifice which the Lord through the prophet said is offered to Him from the rising to the setting of the sun.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:51
verses.text: The body and blood of Christ are making for the support of our soul and body, without being consumed or suffering corruption, not making for the draught (God forbid!) but for our being and preservation, a protection against all kinds of injury, a purging from all uncleanness: should one receive base gold, they purify it by the critical burning lest in the future we be condemned with this world.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:52
verses.text: They purify from diseases and all kinds of calamities; according to the words of the divine Apostle, For if we would judge ourselves, we should not be judged.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:53
verses.text: But when we are judged, we are chastened of the Lord, that we should not be condemned with the world.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:54
verses.text: This too is what he says, So that he that partaketh of the body and blood of Christ unworthily, eateth and drinketh damnation to himself.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:55
verses.text: Being purified by this, we are united to the body of Christ and to His Spirit and become the body of Christ.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:56
verses.text: This bread is the first-fruits of the future bread which is ἐπιούσιος, i-e: necessary for existence.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:57
verses.text: For the word ἐπιούσιον signifies either the future, that is Him Who is for a future age, or else Him of Whom we partake for the preservation of our essence.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:58
verses.text: Whether then it is in this sense or that, it is fitting to speak so of the Lord's body.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:59
verses.text: For the Lord's flesh is life-giving spirit because it was conceived of the life-giving Spirit.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:60
verses.text: For what is born of the Spirit is spirit.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:61
verses.text: But I do not say this to take away the nature of the body, but I wish to make clear its life-giving and divine power.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:62
verses.text: But if some persons called the bread and the wine antitypes of the body and blood of the Lord, as did the divinely inspired Basil, they said so not after the consecration but before the consecration, so calling the offering itself.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:63
verses.text: Participation is spoken of; for through it we partake of the divinity of Jesus.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:64
verses.text: Communion, too, is spoken of, and it is an actual communion, because through it we have communion with Christ and share in His flesh and His divinity: yea, we have communion and are united with one another through it.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:65
verses.text: For since we partake of one bread, we all become one body of Christ and one blood, and members one of another, being of one body with Christ.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:66
verses.text: With all our strength, therefore, let us beware lest we receive communion from or grant it to heretics; Give not that which is holy unto the dogs, saith the Lord, neither cast ye your pearls before swine, lest we become partakers in their dishonour and condemnation.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:67
verses.text: For if union is in truth with Christ and with one another, we are assuredly voluntarily united also with all those who partake with us.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:68
verses.text: For this union is effected voluntarily and not against our inclination.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:69
verses.text: For we are all one body because we partake of the one bread, as the divine Apostle says.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 13:70
verses.text: Further, antitypes of future things are spoken of, not as though they were not in reality Christ's body and blood, but that now through them we partake of Christ's divinity, while then we shall partake mentally through the vision alone.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:1
verses.text: Chapter XIV.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:2
verses.text: —Concerning our Lord's genealogy and concerning the holy Mother of God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:3
verses.text: Concerning the holy and much-lauded ever-virgin one, Mary, the Mother of God, we have said something in the preceding chapters, bringing forward what was most opportune, viz.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:4
verses.text: , that strictly and truly she is and is called the Mother of God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:5
verses.text: Now let us fill up the blanks.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:6
verses.text: For she being pre-ordained by the eternal prescient counsel of God and imaged forth and proclaimed in diverse images and discourses of the prophets through the Holy Spirit, sprang at the pre-determined time from the root of David, according to the promises that were made to him.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:7
verses.text: For the Lord hath sworn, He saith in truth to David, He will not turn from it: of the fruit of Thy body will I set upon Thy throne.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:8
verses.text: And again, Once have I sworn by My holiness, that I will not lie unto David.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:9
verses.text: His seed shall endure for ever, and His throne as the sun before Me.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:10
verses.text: It shall be established for ever as the moon, and as a faithful witness in heaven.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:11
verses.text: And Isaiah says: And there shall come out a rod out of the stem of Jesse and a branch shall grow out of his roots.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:12
verses.text: But that Joseph is descended from the tribe of David is expressly demonstrated by Matthew and Luke, the most holy evangelists.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:13
verses.text: But Matthew derives Joseph from David through Solomon, while Luke does so through Nathan; while over the holy Virgin's origin both pass in silence.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:14
verses.text: One ought to remember that it was not the custom of the Hebrews nor of the divine Scripture to give genealogies of women; and the law was to prevent one tribe seeking wives from another.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:15
verses.text: And so since Joseph was descended from the tribe of David and was a just man (for this the divine Gospel testifies), he would not have espoused the holy Virgin contrary to the law; he would not have taken her unless she had been of the same tribe.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:16
verses.text: It was sufficient, therefore, to demonstrate the descent of Joseph.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:17
verses.text: One ought also to observe this, that the law was that when a man died without seed, this man's brother should take to wife the wife of the dead man and raise up seed to his brother.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:18
verses.text: The offspring, therefore, belonged by nature to the second, that is, to him that begat it, but by law to the dead.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:19
verses.text: Born then of the line of Nathan, the son of David, Levi begat Melchi and Panther: Panther begat Barpanther, so called.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:20
verses.text: This Barpanther begat Joachim: Joachim begat the holy Mother of God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:21
verses.text: And of the line of Solomon, the son of David, Mathan had a wife of whom he begat Jacob.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:22
verses.text: Now on the death of Mathan, Melchi, of the tribe of Nathan, the son of Levi and brother of Panther, married the wife of Mathan, Jacob's mother, of whom he begat Heli.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:23
verses.text: Therefore Jacob and Heli became brothers on the mother's side, Jacob being of the tribe of Solomon and Heli of the tribe of Nathan.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:24
verses.text: Then Heli of the tribe of Nathan died childless, and Jacob his brother, of the tribe of Solomon, took his wife and raised up seed to his brother and begat Joseph.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:25
verses.text: Joseph, therefore, is by nature the son of Jacob, of the line of Solomon, but by law he is the son of Heli of the line of Nathan.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:26
verses.text: Joachim then took to wife that revered and praiseworthy woman, Anna.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:27
