verses.text: But just as the earlier Anna, who was barren, bore Samuel by prayer and by promise, so also this Anna by supplication and promise from God bare the Mother of God in order that she might not even in this be behind the matrons of fame.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:28
verses.text: Accordingly it was grace (for this is the interpretation of Anna) that bore the lady: (for she became truly the Lady of all created things in becoming the Mother of the Creator).

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:29
verses.text: Further, Joachim was born in the house of the Probatica, and was brought up to the temple.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:30
verses.text: Then planted in the House of God and increased by the Spirit, like a fruitful olive tree, she became the home of every virtue, turning her mind away from every secular and carnal desire, and thus keeping her soul as well as her body virginal, as was meet for her who was to receive God into her bosom: for as He is holy, He finds rest among the holy.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:31
verses.text: Thus, therefore, she strove after holiness, and was declared a holy and wonderful temple fit for the most high God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:32
verses.text: Moreover, since the enemy of our salvation was keeping a watchful eye on virgins, according to the prophecy of Isaiah, who said, Behold a virgin shall conceive and bare a Son and shall call His name Emmanuel, which is, being interpreted, 'God with us,' in order that he who taketh the wise in their own craftinessmay deceive him who always glorieth in his wisdom, the maiden is given in marriage to Joseph by the priests, a new book to him who is versed in letters: but the marriage was both the protection of the virgin and the delusion of him who was keeping a watchful eye on virgins.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:33
verses.text: But when the fulness of time was come, the messenger of the Lord was sent to her, with the good news of our Lord's conception.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:34
verses.text: And thus she conceived the Son of God, the hypostatic power of the Father, not of the will of the flesh nor of the will of man, that is to say, by connection and seed, but by the good pleasure of the Father and co-operation of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:35
verses.text: She ministered to the Creator in that He was created, to the Fashioner in that He was fashioned, and to the Son of God and God in that He was made flesh and became man from her pure and immaculate flesh and blood, satisfying the debt of the first mother.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:36
verses.text: For just as the latter was formed from Adam without connection, so also did the former bring forth the new Adam, who was brought forth in accordance with the laws of parturition and above the nature of generation.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:37
verses.text: For He who was of the Father, yet without mother, was born of woman without a father's co-operation.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:38
verses.text: And so far as He was born of woman, His birth was in accordance with the laws of parturition, while so far as He had no father, His birth was above the nature of generation: and in that it was at the usual time (for He was born on the completion of the ninth month when the tenth was just beginning), His birth was in accordance with the laws of parturition, while in that it was painless it was above the laws of generation.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:39
verses.text: For, as pleasure did not precede it, pain did not follow it, according to the prophet who says, Before she travailed, she brought forth, and again, before her pain came she was delivered of a man-child.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:40
verses.text: The Son of God incarnate, therefore, was born of her, not a divinely-inspired man but God incarnate; not a prophet anointed with energy but by the presence of the anointing One in His completeness, so that the Anointer became man and the Anointed God, not by a change of nature but by union in subsistence.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:41
verses.text: For the Anointer and the Anointed were one and the same, anointing in the capacity of God Himself as man.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:42
verses.text: Must there not therefore be a Mother of God who bore God incarnate? Assuredly she who played the part of the Creator's servant and mother is in all strictness and truth in reality God's Mother and Lady and Queen over all created things.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:43
verses.text: But just as He who was conceived kept her who conceived still virgin, in like manner also He who was born preserved her virginity intact, only passing through her and keeping her closed.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:44
verses.text: The conception, indeed, was through the sense of hearing, but the birth through the usual path by which children come, although some tell tales of His birth through the side of the Mother of God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:45
verses.text: For it was not impossible for Him to have come by this gate, without injuring her seal in anyway.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:46
verses.text: The ever-virgin One thus remains even after the birth still virgin, having never at any time up till death consorted with a man.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:47
verses.text: For although it is written, And knew her not till she had brought forth her first-born Son, yet note that he who is first-begotten is first-born even if he is only-begotten.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:48
verses.text: For the word "first-born" means that he was born first but does not at all suggest the birth of others.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:49
verses.text: And the word "till" signifies the limit of the appointed time but does not exclude the time thereafter.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:50
verses.text: For the Lord says, And lo, I am with you always, even unto the end of the world, not meaning thereby that He will be separated from us after the completion of the age.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:51
verses.text: The divine apostle, indeed, says, And so shall we ever be with the Lord, meaning after the general resurrection.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:52
verses.text: For could it be possible that she, who had borne God and from experience of the subsequent events had come to know the miracle, should receive the embrace of a man.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:53
verses.text: God forbid! It is not the part of a chaste mind to think such thoughts, far less to commit such acts.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:54
verses.text: But this blessed woman, who was deemed worthy of gifts that are supernatural, suffered those pains, which she escaped at the birth, in the hour of the passion, enduring from motherly sympathy the rending of the bowels, and when she beheld Him, Whom she knew to be God by the manner of His generation, killed as a malefactor, her thoughts pierced her as a sword, and this is the meaning of this verse: Yea, a sword shall pierce through thy own soul also.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 14:55
verses.text: But the joy of the resurrection transforms the pain, proclaiming Him, Who died in the flesh, to be God.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:1
verses.text: Chapter XV.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:2
verses.text: —Concerning the honour due to the Saints and their remains.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:3
verses.text: To the saints honour must be paid as friends of Christ, as sons and heirs of God: in the words of John the theologian and evangelist, As many as received Him, to them gave He power to became sons of God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:4
verses.text: So that they are no longer servants, but sons: and if sons, also heirs, heirs of God and joint heirs with Christ: and the Lord in the holy Gospels says to His apostles, Ye are My friends.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:5
verses.text: Henceforth I call you not servants, for the servant knoweth not what his lord doeth.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:6
verses.text: And further, if the Creator and Lord of all things is called also King of Kings and Lord of Lords and God of Gods, surely also the saints are gods and lords and kings.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:7
verses.text: For of these God is and is called God and Lord and King.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:8
verses.text: For I am the God of Abraham, He said to Moses, the God of Isaac and the God of Jacob.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:9
verses.text: And God made Moses a god to Pharaoh.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:10
verses.text: Now I mean gods and kings and lords not in nature, but as rulers and masters of their passions, and as preserving a truthful likeness to the divine image according to which they were made (for the image of a king is also called king), and as being united to God of their own free-will and receiving Him as an indweller and becoming by grace through participation with Him what He is Himself by nature.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:11
verses.text: Surely, then, the worshippers and friends and sons of God are to be held in honour? For the honour shewn to the most thoughtful of fellow-servants is a proof of good feeling towards the common Master.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:12
verses.text: These are made treasuries and pure habitations of God: For I will dwell in them, said God, and walk in them, and I will be their God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:13
verses.text: The divine Scripture likewise saith that the souls of the just are in God's hand and death cannot lay hold of them.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:14
verses.text: For death is rather the sleep of the saints than their death.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:15
verses.text: For they travailed in this life and shall to the end, and Precious in the sight of the Lord is the death of His saints.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:16
verses.text: What then, is more precious than to be in the hand of God? For God is Life and Light, and those who are in God's hand are in life and light.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:17
verses.text: Further, that God dwelt even in their bodies in spiritual wise, the Apostle tells us, saying, Know ye not that your bodies are the temples of the Holy Spirit dwelling in you?, and The Lord is that Spirit, and If any one destroy the temple of God, him will God destroy.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:18
verses.text: Surely, then, we must ascribe honour to the living temples of God, the living tabernacles of God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:19
verses.text: These while they lived stood with confidence before God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:20
verses.text: The Master Christ made the remains of the saints to be fountains of salvation to us, pouring forth manifold blessings and abounding in oil of sweet fragrance: and let no one disbelieve this.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:21
verses.text: For if water burst in the desert from the steep and solid rock at God's will and from the jaw-bone of an ass to quench Samson's thirst, is it incredible that fragrant oil should burst forth from the martyrs' remains? By no means, at least to those who know the power of God and the honour which He accords His saints.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:22
verses.text: In the law every one who toucheth a dead body was considered impure, but these are not dead.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:23
verses.text: For from the time when He that is Himself life and the Author of life was reckoned among the dead, we do not call those dead who have fallen asleep in the hope of the resurrection and in faith on Him.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:24
verses.text: For how could a dead body work miracles? How, therefore, are demons driven off by them, diseases dispelled, sick persons made well, the blind restored to sight, lepers purified, temptations and troubles overcome, and how does every good gift from the Father of lights come down through them to those who pray with sure faith? How much labour would you not undergo to find a patron to introduce you to a mortal king and speak to him on your behalf? Are not those, then, worthy of honour who are the patrons of the whole race, and make intercession to God for us? Yea, verily, we ought to give honour to them by raising temples to God in their name, bringing them fruit-offerings, honouring their memories and taking spiritual delight in them, in order that the joy of those who call on us may be ours, that in our attempts at worship we may not on the contrary cause them offence.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:25
verses.text: For those who worship God will take pleasure in those things whereby God is worshipped, while His shield-bearers will be wrath at those things wherewith God is wroth.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:26
verses.text: In psalms and hymns and spiritual songs, in contrition and in pity for the needy, let us believers worship the saints, as God also is most worshipped in such wise.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:27
verses.text: Let us raise monuments to them and visible images, and let us ourselves become, through imitation of their virtues, living monuments and images of them.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:28
verses.text: Let us give honour to her who bore God as being strictly and truly the Mother of God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:29
verses.text: Let us honour also the prophet John as forerunner and baptist, as apostle and martyr, For among them that are born of women there hath not risen a greater than John the Baptist, as saith the Lord, and he became the first to proclaim the Kingdom.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:30
verses.text: Let us honour the apostles as the Lord's brothers, who saw Him face to face and ministered to His passion, for whom God the Father did foreknow He also did predestinate to be conformed to the image of His Son, first apostles, second prophets, third pastors and teachers.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:31
verses.text: Let us also honour the martyrs of the Lord chosen out of every class, as soldiers of Christ who have drunk His cup and were then baptized with the baptism of His life-bringing death, to be partakers of His passion and glory: of whom the leader is Stephen, the first deacon of Christ and apostle and first martyr.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:32
verses.text: Also let us honour our holy fathers, the God-possessed ascetics, whose struggle was the longer and more toilsome one of the conscience: who wandered about in sheepskins and goatskins, being destitute, afflicted, tormented; they wandered in deserts and in mountains and in dens and caves of the earth, of whom the world was not worthy.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:33
verses.text: Let us honour those who were prophets before grace, the patriarchs and just men who foretold the Lord's coming.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 15:34
verses.text: Let us carefully review the life of these men, and let us emulate their faith and love and hope and zeal and way of life, and endurance of sufferings and patience even to blood, in order that we may be sharers with them in their crowns of glory.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:1
verses.text: Chapter XVI.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:2
verses.text: —Concerning Images.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:3
verses.text: But since some find fault with us for worshipping and honouring the image of our Saviour and that of our Lady, and those, too, of the rest of the saints and servants of Christ, let them remember that in the beginning God created man after His own image.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:4
verses.text: On what grounds, then, do we shew reverence to each other unless because we are made after God's image? For as Basil, that much-versed expounder of divine things, says, the honour given to the image passes over to the prototype.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:5
verses.text: Now a prototype is that which is imaged, from which the derivative is obtained.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:6
verses.text: Why was it that the Mosaic people honoured on all hands the tabernacle which bore an image and type of heavenly things, or rather of the whole creation? God indeed said to Moses, Look that thou make them after their pattern which was shewed thee in the mount.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:7
verses.text: The Cherubim, too, which o'ershadow the mercy seat, are they not the work of men's hands? What, further, is the celebrated temple at Jerusalem? Is it not hand-made and fashioned by the skill of men?  Moreover the divine Scripture blames those who worship graven images, but also those who sacrifice to demons.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:8
verses.text: The Greeks sacrificed and the Jews also sacrificed: but the Greeks to demons and the Jews to God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:9
verses.text: And the sacrifice of the Greeks was rejected and condemned, but the sacrifice of the just was very acceptable to God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:10
verses.text: For Noah sacrificed, and God smelled a sweet savour, receiving the fragrance of the right choice and good-will towards Him.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:11
verses.text: And so the graven images of the Greeks, since they were images of deities, were rejected and forbidden.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:12
verses.text: But besides this who can make an imitation of the invisible, incorporeal, uncircumscribed, formless God? Therefore to give form to the Deity is the height of folly and impiety.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:13
verses.text: And hence it is that in the Old Testament the use of images was not common.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:14
verses.text: But after God in His bowels of pity became in truth man for our salvation, not as He was seen by Abraham in the semblance of a man, nor as He was seen by the prophets, but in being truly man, and after He lived upon the earth and dwelt among men, worked miracles, suffered, was crucified, rose again and was taken back to Heaven, since all these things actually took place and were seen by men, they were written for the remembrance and instruction of us who were not alive at that time in order that though we saw not, we may still, hearing and believing, obtain the blessing of the Lord.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:15
verses.text: But seeing that not every one has a knowledge of letters nor time for reading, the Fathers gave their sanction to depicting these events on images as being acts of great heroism, in order that they should form a concise memorial of them.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:16
verses.text: Often, doubtless, when we have not the Lord's passion in mind and see the image of Christ's crucifixion, His saving passion is brought back to remembrance, and we fall down and worship not the material but that which is imaged: just as we do not worship the material of which the Gospels are made, nor the material of the Cross, but that which these typify.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:17
verses.text: For wherein does the cross, that typifies the Lord, differ from a cross that does not do so? It is just the same also in the case of the Mother of the Lord.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:18
verses.text: For the honour which we give to her is referred to Him Who was made of her incarnate.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:19
verses.text: And similarly also the brave acts of holy men stir us up to be brave and to emulate and imitate their valour and to glorify God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:20
verses.text: For as we said, the honour that is given to the best of fellow-servants is a proof of good-will towards our common Lady, and the honour rendered to the image passes over to the prototype.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:21
verses.text: But this is an unwritten tradition, just as is also the worshipping towards the East and the worship of the Cross, and very many other similar things.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:22
verses.text: A certain tale, too, is told, how that when Augarus was king over the city of the Edessenes, he sent a portrait painter to paint a likeness of the Lord, and when the painter could not paint because of the brightness that shone from His countenance, the Lord Himself put a garment over His own divine and life-giving face and impressed on it an image of Himself and sent this to Augarus, to satisfy thus his desire.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:23
verses.text: Moreover that the Apostles handed down much that was unwritten, Paul, the Apostle of the Gentiles, tells us in these words: Therefore, brethren, stand fast and hold the traditions which ye have been taught of us, whether by word or by epistle.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 16:24
verses.text: And to the Corinthians he writes, Now I praise you, brethren, that ye remember me in all things, and keep the traditions as I have delivered them to you".

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:1
verses.text: Chapter XVII.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:2
verses.text: —Concerning Scripture.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:3
verses.text: It is one and the same God Whom both the Old and the New Testament proclaim, Who is praised and glorified in the Trinity: I am come, saith the Lord, not to destroy the law but to fulfil it.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:4
verses.text: For He Himself worked out our salvation for which all Scripture and all mystery exists.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:5
verses.text: And again, Search the Scriptures for they are they that testify of Me.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:6
verses.text: And the Apostle says, God, Who at sundry times and in diverse manners spake in time past unto the fathers by the prophets, hath in these last days spoken unto us by His Son.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:7
verses.text: Through the Holy Spirit, therefore, both the law and the prophets, the evangelists and apostles and pastors and teachers, spake.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:8
verses.text: All Scripture, then, is given by inspiration of God and is also assuredly profitable.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:9
verses.text: Wherefore to search the Scriptures is a work most fair and most profitable for souls.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:10
verses.text: For just as the tree planted by the channels of waters, so also the soul watered by the divine Scripture is enriched and gives fruit in its season, viz.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:11
verses.text: orthodox belief, and is adorned with evergreen leafage, I mean, actions pleasing to God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:12
verses.text: For through the Holy Scriptures we are trained to action that is pleasing to God, and untroubled contemplation.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:13
verses.text: For in these we find both exhortation to every virtue and dissuasion from every vice.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:14
verses.text: If, therefore, we are lovers of learning, we shall also be learned in many things.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:15
verses.text: For by care and toil and the grace of God the Giver, all things are accomplished.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:16
verses.text: For every one that asketh receiveth, and he that seeketh findeth, and to him that knocketh it shall be opened.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:17
verses.text: Wherefore let us knock at that very fair garden of the Scriptures, so fragrant and sweet and blooming, with its varied sounds of spiritual and divinely-inspired birds ringing all round our ears, laying hold of our hearts, comforting the mourner, pacifying the angry and filling him with joy everlasting: which sets our mind on the gold-gleaming, brilliant back of the divine dove, whose bright pinions bear up to the only-begotten Son and Heir of the Husbandman of that spiritual Vineyard and bring us through Him to the Father of Lights.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:18
verses.text: But let us not knock carelessly but rather zealously and constantly: lest knocking we grow weary.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:19
verses.text: For thus it will be opened to us.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:20
verses.text: If we read once or twice and do not understand what we read, let us not grow weary, but let us persist, let us talk much, let us enquire.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:21
verses.text: For ask thy Father, he saith, and He will shew thee: thy elders and they will tell thee.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:22
verses.text: For there is not in every man that knowledge.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:23
verses.text: Let us draw of the fountain of the garden perennial and purest waters springing into life eternal.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:24
verses.text: Here let us luxuriate, let us revel insatiate: for the Scriptures possess inexhaustible grace.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:25
verses.text: But if we are able to pluck anything profitable from outside sources, there is nothing to forbid that.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:26
verses.text: Let us become tried money-dealers, heaping up the true and pure gold and discarding the spurious.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:27
verses.text: Let us keep the fairest sayings but let us throw to the dogs absurd gods and strange myths: for we might prevail most mightily against them through themselves.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:28
verses.text: Observe, further, that there are two and twenty books of the Old Testament, one for each letter of the Hebrew tongue.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:29
verses.text: For there are twenty-two letters of which five are double, and so they come to be twenty-seven.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:30
verses.text: For the letters Caph, Mem, Nun, Pe, Sade are double.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:31
verses.text: And thus the number of the books in this way is twenty-two, but is found to be twenty-seven because of the double character of five.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:32
verses.text: For Ruth is joined on to Judges, and the Hebrews count them one book: the first and second books of Kings are counted one: and so are the third and fourth books of Kings: and also the first and second of Paraleipomena: and the first and second of Esdra.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:33
verses.text: In this way, then, the books are collected together in four Pentateuchs and two others remain over, to form thus the canonical books.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:34
verses.text: Five of them are of the Law, viz.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:35
verses.text: Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers, Deuteronomy.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:36
verses.text: This which is the code of the Law, constitutes the first Pentateuch.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:37
verses.text: Then comes another Pentateuch, the so-called Grapheia, or as they are called by some, the Hagiographa, which are the following: Jesus the Son of Nave, Judges along with Ruth, first and second Kings, which are one book, third and fourth Kings, which are one book, and the two books of the Paraleipomena which are one book.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:38
verses.text: This is the second Pentateuch.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:39
verses.text: The third Pentateuch is the books in verse, viz.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:40
verses.text: Job, Psalms, Proverbs of Solomon, Ecclesiastes of Solomon and the Song of Songs of Solomon.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:41
verses.text: The fourth Pentateuch is the Prophetical books, viz the twelve prophets constituting one book, Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel, Daniel.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:42
verses.text: Then come the two books of Esdra made into one, and Esther.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:43
verses.text: There are also the Panaretus, that is the Wisdom of Solomon, and the Wisdom of Jesus, which was published in Hebrew by the father of Sirach, and afterwards translated into Greek by his grandson, Jesus, the Son of Sirach.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:44
verses.text: These are virtuous and noble, but are not counted nor were they placed in the ark.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:45
verses.text: The New Testament contains four gospels, that according to Matthew, that according to Mark, that according to Luke, that according to John: the Acts of the Holy Apostles by Luke the Evangelist: seven catholic epistles, viz.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 17:46
verses.text: one of James, two of Peter, three of John, one of Jude: fourteen letters of the Apostle Paul: the Revelation of John the Evangelist: the Canons of the holy apostles, by Clement.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:1
verses.text: Chapter XVIII.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:2
verses.text: —Regarding the things said concerning Christ.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:3
verses.text: The things said concerning Christ fall into four generic modes.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:4
verses.text: For some fit Him even before the incarnation, others in the union, others after the union, and others after the resurrection.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:5
verses.text: Also of those that refer to the period before the incarnation there are six modes: for some of them declare the union of nature and the identity in essence with the Father, as this, I and My Father are one: also this, He that hath seen Me hath seen the Father: and this, Who being in the form of God, and so forth.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:6
verses.text: Others declare the perfection of subsistence, as these, Son of God, and the Express Image of His person, and Messenger of great counsel, Wonderful Counsellor, and the like.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:7
verses.text: Again, others declare the indwelling of the subsistences in one another, as, I am in the Father and the Father in Me; and the inseparable foundation, as, for instance, the Word, Wisdom, Power, Effulgence.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:8
verses.text: For the word is inseparably established in the mind (and it is the essential mind that I mean), and so also is wisdom, and power in him that is powerful, and effulgence in the light, all springing forth from these.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:9
verses.text: And others make known the fact of His origin from the Father as cause, for instance My Father is greater than I.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:10
verses.text: For from Him He derives both His being and all that He has: His being was by generative and not by creative means, as, I came forth from the Father and am come, and I live by the Father.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:11
verses.text: But all that He hath is not His by free gift or by teaching, but in a causal sense, as, The Son can do nothing of Himself but what He seeth the Father do.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:12
verses.text: For if the Father is not, neither is the Son.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:13
verses.text: For the Son is of the Father and in the Father and with the Father, and not after the Father.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:14
verses.text: In like manner also what He doeth is of Him and with Him.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:15
verses.text: For there is one and the same, not similar but the same, will and energy and power in the Father, Son and Holy Spirit.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:16
verses.text: Moreover, other things are said as though the Father's good-will was fulfilled through His energy, and not as through an instrument or a servant, but as through His essential and hypostatic Word and Wisdom and Power, because but one action is observed in Father and Son, as for example, All things were made by Him, and He sent His Word and healed them, and That they may believe that Thou hast sent Me.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:17
verses.text: Some, again, have a prophetic sense, and of these some are in the future tense: for instance, He shall come openly, and this from Zechariah, Behold, thy King cometh unto thee, and this from Micah, Behold, the Lord cometh out of His place and will come down and tread upon the high places of the earth.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:18
verses.text: But others, though future, are put in the past tense, as, for instance, This is our God: Therefore He was seen upon the earth and dwelt among men, and The Lord created me in the beginning of His ways for His works, and Wherefore God, thy God, anointed thee with the oil of gladness above thy fellows, and such like.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:19
verses.text: The things said, then, that refer to the period before the union will be applicable to Him even after the union: but those that refer to the period after the union will not be applicable at all before the union, unless indeed in a prophetic sense, as we said.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:20
verses.text: Those that refer to the time of the union have three modes.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:21
verses.text: For when our discourse deals with the higher aspect, we speak of the deification of the flesh, and His assumption of the Word and exceeding exaltation, and so forth, making manifest the riches that are added to the flesh from the union and natural conjunction with the most high God the Word.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:22
verses.text: And when our discourse deals with the lower aspect, we speak of the incarnation of God the Word, His becoming man, His emptying of Himself, His poverty, His humility.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:23
verses.text: For these and such like are imposed upon the Word and God through His admixture with humanity.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:24
verses.text: When again we keep both sides in view at the same time, we speak of union, community, anointing, natural conjunction, conformation and the like.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:25
verses.text: The former two modes, then, have their reason in this third mode.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:26
verses.text: For through the union it is made clear what either has obtained from the intimate junction with and permeation through the other.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:27
verses.text: For through the union in subsistence the flesh is said to be deified and to become God and to be equally God with the Word; and God the Word is said to be made flesh, and to become man, and is called creature and last: not in the sense that the two natures are converted into one compound nature (for it is not possible for the opposite natural qualities to exist at the same time in one nature), but in the sense that the two natures are united in subsistence and permeate one another without confusion or transmutation.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:28
verses.text: The permeation moreover did not come of the flesh but of the divinity: for it is impossible that the flesh should permeate through the divinity: but the divine nature once permeating through the flesh gave also to the flesh the same ineffable power of permeation; and this indeed is what we call union.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:29
verses.text: Note, too, that in the case of the first and second modes of those that belong to the period of the union, reciprocation is observed.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:30
verses.text: For when we speak about the flesh, we use the terms deification and assumption of the Word and exceeding exaltation and anointing.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:31
verses.text: For these are derived from divinity, but are observed in connection with the flesh.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:32
verses.text: And when we speak about the Word, we use the terms emptying, incarnation, becoming man, humility and the like: and these, as we said, are imposed on the Word and God through the flesh.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:33
verses.text: For He endured these things in person of His own free-will.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:34
verses.text: Of the things that refer to the period after the union there are three modes.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:35
verses.text: The first declares His divine nature, as, I am in the Father and the Father in Me, and I and the Father are one: and all those things which are affirmed of Him before His assumption of humanity, these will be affirmed of Him even after His assumption of humanity, with this exception, that He did not assume the flesh and its natural properties.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:36
verses.text: The second declares His human nature, as, Now ye seek to kill Me, a man that hath told you the truth, and Even so must the Son of Man be lifted up, and the like.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:37
verses.text: Further, of the statements made and written about Christ the Saviour after the manner of men, whether they deal with sayings or actions, there are six modes.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:38
verses.text: For some of them were done or said naturally in accordance with the incarnation; for instance, His birth from a virgin, His growth and progress with age, His hunger, thirst, weariness, fear, sleep, piercing with nails, death and all such like natural and innocent passions.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:39
verses.text: For in all these there is a mixture of the divine and human, although they are held to belong in reality to the body, the divine suffering none of these, but procuring through them our salvation.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:40
verses.text: Others are of the nature of ascription, as Christ's question, Where have ye laid Lazarus? His running to the fig-tree, His shrinking, that is, His drawing back, His praying, and His making as though He would have gone further For neither as God nor as man was He in need of these or similar things, but only because His form was that of a man as necessity and expediency demanded.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:41
verses.text: For example, the praying was to shew that He is not opposed to God, for He gives honour to the Father as the cause of Himself: and the question was not put in ignorance but to shew that He is in truth man as well as God; and the drawing back is to teach us not to be impetuous nor to give ourselves up.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:42
verses.text: Others again are said in the manner of association and relation, as, My God, My God, why hast Thou forsaken Me? and He hath made Him to be sin for us, Who knew no sin, and being made a curse for us; also, Then shall the Son also Himself be subject unto Him that put all things under Him For neither as God nor as man was He ever forsaken by the Father, nor did He become sin or a curse, nor did He require to be made subject to the Father.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:43
verses.text: For as God He is equal to the Father and not opposed to Him nor subjected to Him; and as God, He was never at any time disobedient to His Begetter to make it necessary for Him to make Him subject.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:44
verses.text: Appropriating, then, our person and ranking Himself with us, He used these words.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:45
verses.text: For we are bound in the fetters of sin and the curse as faithless and disobedient, and therefore forsaken.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:46
verses.text: Others are said by reason of distinction in thought.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:47
verses.text: For if you divide in thought things that are inseparable in actual truth, to cut the flesh from the Word, the terms 'servant' and 'ignorant' are used of Him, for indeed He was of a subject and ignorant nature, and except that it was united with God the Word, His flesh was servile and ignorant.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:48
verses.text: But because of the union in subsistence with God the Word it was neither servile nor ignorant.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:49
verses.text: In this way, too, He called the Father His God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:50
verses.text: Others again are for the purpose of revealing Him to us and strengthening our faith, as, And now, O Father, glorify Thou Me with the glory which I had with Thee, before the world was.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:51
verses.text: For He Himself was glorified and is glorified, but His glory was not manifested nor confirmed to us.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:52
verses.text: Also that which the apostle said, Declared to be the Son of God with power, according to the spirit of holiness, by the resurrection from the dead.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:53
verses.text: For by the miracles and the resurrection and the coming of the Holy Spirit it was manifested and confirmed to the world that He is the Son of God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:54
verses.text: And this too, The Child grew in wisdom and grace.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:55
verses.text: Others again have reference to His appropriation of the personal life of the Jews, in numbering Himself among the Jews, as He saith to the Samaritan woman, Ye worship ye know not what: we know what we worship, far salvation is of the Jews.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:56
verses.text: The third mode is one which declares the one subsistence and brings out the dual nature: for instance, And I live by the Father: so he that eateth Me, even he shall live by Me.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:57
verses.text: And this: I go to My Father and ye see Me no more.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:58
verses.text: And this: They would not have crucified the Lord of Glory.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:59
verses.text: And this: And no man hath ascended up to heaven but He that came down from heaven, even the Son of Man which is in heaven, and such like.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:60
verses.text: Again of the affirmations that refer to the period after the resurrection some are suitable to God, as, Baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost, for here 'Son' is clearly used as God; also this, And lo, I am with you alway, even unto the end of the world, and other similar ones.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:61
verses.text: For He is with us as God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:62
verses.text: Others are suitable to man, as, They held Him by the feet, and There they will see Me, and so forth.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:63
verses.text: Further, of those referring to the period after the Resurrection that are suitable to man there are different modes.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:64
verses.text: For some did actually take place, yet not according to nature, but according to dispensation, in order to confirm the fact that the very body, which suffered, rose again; such are the weals, the eating and the drinking after the resurrection.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:65
verses.text: Others took place actually and naturally, as changing from place to place without trouble and passing in through closed gates.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:66
verses.text: Others have the character of simulation, as, He made as though He would have gone further.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:67
verses.text: Others are appropriate to the double nature, as, I ascend unto My Father and your Father, and My God and your God, and The King of Glory shall come in, and He sat down on the right hand of the majesty on High.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:68
verses.text: Finally others are to be understood as though He were ranking Himself with us, in the manner of separation in pure thought, as, My God and your God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:69
verses.text: Those then that are sublime must be assigned to the divine nature, which is superior to passion and body: and those that are humble must be ascribed to the human nature; and those that are common must be attributed to the compound, that is, the one Christ, Who is God and man.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:70
verses.text: And it should be understood that both belong to one and the same Jesus Christ, our Lord.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:71
verses.text: For if we know what is proper to each, and perceive that both are performed by one and the same, we shall have the true faith and shall not go astray.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:72
verses.text: And from all these the difference between the united natures is recognised, and the fact that, as the most godly Cyril says, they are not identical in the natural quality of their divinity and humanity.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 18:73
verses.text: But yet there is but one Son and Christ and Lord: and as He is one, He has also but one person, the unity in subsistence being in nowise broken up into parts by the recognition of the difference of the natures.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:1
verses.text: Chapter XIX.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:2
verses.text: —That God is not the cause of evils.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:3
verses.text: It is to be observed that it is the custom in the Holy Scripture to speak of God's permission as His energy, as when the apostle says in the Epistle to the Romans, Hath not the potter power over the clay, of the same lump to make one vessel unto honour and another unto dishonour? And for this reason, that He Himself makes this or that.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:4
verses.text: For He is Himself alone the Maker of all things; yet it is not He Himself that fashions noble or ignoble things, but the personal choice of each one.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:5
verses.text: And this is manifest from what the same Apostle says in the Second Epistle to Timothy, In a great house there are not only vessels of gold and of silver, but also of wood and of earth: and some to honour and some to dishonour.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:6
verses.text: If a man therefore purge himself from these, he shall be a vessel unto honour sanctified, and meet for the master's use, and prepared unto every good work.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:7
verses.text: And it is evident that the purification must be voluntary: for if a man, he saith, purge himself.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:8
verses.text: And the consequent antistrophe responds, "If a man purge not himself he will be a vessel to dishonour, unmeet for the master's use and fit only to be broken in pieces".

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:9
verses.text: Wherefore this passage that we have quoted and this, God hath concluded them all in unbelief, and this, God hath given them the spirit of slumber, eyes that they should not see, and ears that they should not hear, all these must be understood not as though God Himself were energising, but as though God were permitting, both because of free-will and because goodness knows no compulsion.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:10
verses.text: His permission, therefore, is usually spoken of in the Holy Scripture as His energy and work.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:11
verses.text: Nay, even when He says that God creates evil things, and that there is no evil in a city that the Lord hath not done, he does not mean by these words that the Lord is the cause of evil, but the word 'evil' is used in two ways, with two meanings.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:12
verses.text: For sometimes it means what is evil by nature, and this is the opposite of virtue and the will of God: and sometimes it means that which is evil and oppressive to our sensation, that is to say, afflictions and calamities.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:13
verses.text: Now these are seemingly evil because they are painful, but in reality are good.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:14
verses.text: For to those who understand they became ambassadors of conversion and salvation.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:15
verses.text: The Scripture says that of these God is the Author.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:16
verses.text: It is, moreover, to be observed that of these, too, we are the cause: for involuntary evils are the offspring of voluntary ones.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:17
verses.text: This also should be recognised, that it is usual in the Scriptures for some things that ought to be considered as effects to be stated in a causal sense, as, Against Thee, Thee only, have I sinned and done this evil in Thy sight, that Thou mightest be justified when Thou speakest, and prevail when Thou judgest.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:18
verses.text: For the sinner did not sin in order that God might prevail, nor again did God require our sin in order that He might by it be revealed as victor.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:19
verses.text: For above comparison He wins the victor's prize against all, even against those who are sinless, being Maker, incomprehensible, uncreated, and possessing natural and not adventitious glory.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:20
verses.text: But it is because when we sin God is not unjust in His anger against us; and when He pardons the penitent He is shewn victor over our wickedness.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:21
verses.text: But it is not for this that we sin, but because the thing so turns out.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:22
verses.text: It is just as if one were sitting at work and a friend stood near by, and one said, My friend came in order that I might do no work that day.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:23
verses.text: The friend, however, was not present in order that the man should do no work, but such was the result.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:24
verses.text: For being occupied with receiving his friend he did not work.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:25
verses.text: These things, too, are spoken of as effects because affairs so turned out.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 19:26
verses.text: Moreover, God does not wish that He alone should be just, but that all should, so far as possible, be made like unto Him.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:1
verses.text: Chapter XX.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:2
verses.text: —That there are not two Kingdoms.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:3
verses.text: That there are not two kingdoms, one good and one bad, we shall see from this.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:4
verses.text: For good and evil are opposed to one another and mutually destructive, and cannot exist in one another or with one another.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:5
verses.text: Each of them, therefore, in its own division will belong to the whole, and first they will be circumscribed, not by the whole alone but also each of them by part of the whole.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:6
verses.text: Next I ask, who it is that assigns to each its place.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:7
verses.text: For they will not affirm that they have come to a friendly agreement with, or been reconciled to, one another.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:8
verses.text: For evil is not evil when it is at peace with, and reconciled to, goodness, nor is goodness good when it is on amicable terms with evil.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:9
verses.text: But if He Who has marked off to each of these its own sphere of action is something different from them, He must the rather be God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:10
verses.text: One of two things indeed is necessary, either that they come in contact with and destroy one another, or that there exists some intermediate place where neither goodness nor evil exists, separating both from one another, like a partition.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:11
verses.text: And so there will be no longer two but three kingdoms.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:12
verses.text: Again, one of these alternatives is necessary, either that they are at peace, which is quite incompatible with evil (for that which is at peace is not evil), or they are at strife, which is incompatible with goodness (for that which is at strife is not perfectly good), or the evil is at strife and the good does not retaliate, but is destroyed by the evil, or they are ever in trouble and distress, which is not a mark of goodness.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:13
verses.text: There is, therefore, but one kingdom, delivered from all evil.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:14
verses.text: But if this is so, they say, whence comes evil? For it is quite impossible that evil should originate from goodness.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:15
verses.text: We answer then, that evil is nothing else than absence of goodness and a lapsing from what is natural into what is unnatural: for nothing evil is natural.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:16
verses.text: For all things, whatsoever God made, are very good, so far as they were made: if, therefore, they remain just as they were created, they are very good, but when they voluntarily depart from what is natural and turn to what is unnatural, they slip into evil.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:17
verses.text: By nature, therefore, all things are servants of the Creator and obey Him.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:18
verses.text: Whenever, then, any of His creatures voluntarily rebels and becomes disobedient to his Maker, he introduces evil into himself.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:19
verses.text: For evil is not any essence nor a property of essence, but an accident, that is, a voluntary deviation from what is natural into what is unnatural, which is sin.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:20
verses.text: Whence, then, comes sin? It is an invention of the free-will of the devil.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:21
verses.text: Is the devil, then, evil? In so far as he was brought into existence he is not evil but good.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:22
verses.text: For he was created by his Maker a bright and very brilliant angel, endowed with free-will as being rational.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:23
verses.text: But he voluntarily departed from the virtue that is natural and came into the darkness of evil, being far removed from God, Who alone is good and can give life and light.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 20:24
verses.text: For from Him every good thing derives its goodness, and so far as it is separated from Him in will (for it is not in place), it falls into evil.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 21

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 21:1
verses.text: Chapter XXI.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 21:2
verses.text: —The purposefor which God in His foreknowledge created persons who would sin and not repent.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 21:3
verses.text: God in His goodness brought what exists into being out of nothing, and has foreknowledge of what will exist in the future.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 21:4
verses.text: If, therefore, they were not to exist in the future, they would neither be evil in the future nor would they be foreknown.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 21:5
verses.text: For knowledge is of what exists and foreknowledge is of what will surely exist in the future.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 21:6
verses.text: For simple being comes first and then good or evil being.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 21:7
verses.text: But if the very existence of those, who through the goodness of God are in the future to exist, were to be prevented by the fact that they were to become evil of their own choice, evil would have prevailed over the goodness of God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 21:8
verses.text: Wherefore God makes all His works good, but each becomes of its own choice good or evil.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 21:9
verses.text: Although, then, the Lord said, Good were it for that man that he had never been born, He said it in condemnation not of His own creation but of the evil which His own creation had acquired by his own choice and through his own heedlessness.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 21:10
verses.text: For the heedlessness that marks man's judgment made His Creator's beneficence of no profit to him.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 21:11
verses.text: It is just as if any one, when he had obtained riches and dominion from a king, were to lord it over his benefactor, who, when he has worsted him, will punish him as he deserves, if he should see him keeping hold of the sovereignty to the end.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 22

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 22:1
verses.text: Chapter XXII.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 22:2
verses.text: —Concerning the law of God and the law of sin.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 22:3
verses.text: The Deity is good and more than good, and so is His will.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 22:4
verses.text: For that which God wishes is good.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 22:5
verses.text: Moreover the precept, which teaches this, is law, that we, holding by it, may walk in light: and the transgression of this precept is sin, and this continues to exist on account of the assault of the devil and our unconstrained and voluntary reception of it.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 22:6
verses.text: And this, too, is called law.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 22:7
verses.text: And so the law of God, settling in our mind, draws it towards itself and pricks our conscience.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 22:8
verses.text: And our conscience, too, is called a law of our mind.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 22:9
verses.text: Further, the assault of the wicked one, that is the law of sin, settling in the members of our flesh, makes its assault upon us through it.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 22:10
verses.text: For by once voluntarily transgressing the law of God and receiving the assault of the wicked one, we gave entrance to it, being sold by ourselves to sin.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 22:11
verses.text: Wherefore our body is readily impelled to it.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 22:12
verses.text: And so the savour and perception of sin that is stored up in our body, that is to say, lust and pleasure of the body, is law in the members of our flesh.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 22:13
verses.text: Therefore the law of my mind, that is, the conscience, sympathises with the law of God, that is, the precept, and makes that its will.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 22:14
verses.text: But the law of sin, that is to say, the assault made through the law that is in our members, or through the lust and inclination and movement of the body and of the irrational part of the soul, is in opposition to the law of my mind, that is to conscience, and takes me captive (even though I make the law of God my will and set my love on it, and make not sin my will), by reason of commixture: and through the softness of pleasure and the lust of the body and of the irrational part of the soul, as I said, it leads me astray and induces me to become the servant of sin.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 22:15
verses.text: But what the law could not do, in that it was weak through the flesh, God, sending His own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh (for He assumed flesh but not sin) condemned sin in the flesh, that the righteousness of the law might be fulfilled in us who walk not after the flesh but in the Spirit.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 22:16
verses.text: For the Spirit helpeth our infirmities and affordeth power to the law of our mind, against the law that is in our members.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 22:17
verses.text: For the verse, we know not what we should pray for as we ought, but the Spirit itself maketh intercession with groanings that cannot be uttered, itself teacheth us what to pray for.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 22:18
verses.text: Hence it is impossible to carry out the precepts of the Lord except by patience and prayer.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIII.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:2
verses.text: —Against the Jews on the question of the Sabbath.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:3
verses.text: The seventh day is called the Sabbath and signifies rest.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:4
verses.text: For in it God rested from all His works, as the divine Scripture says: and so the number of the days goes up to seven and then circles back again and begins at the first.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:5
verses.text: This is the precious number with the Jews, God having ordained that it should be held in honour, and that in no chance fashion but with the imposition of most heavy penalties for the transgression.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:6
verses.text: And it was not in a simple fashion that He ordained this, but for certain reasons understood mystically by the spiritual and clear-sighted.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:7
verses.text: So far, indeed, as I in my ignorance know, to begin with inferior and more dense things, God, knowing the denseness of the Israelites and their carnal love and propensity towards matter in everything, made this law: first, in order that the servant and the cattle should restas it is written, for the righteous man regardeth the life of his beast: next, in order that when they take their ease from the distraction of material things, they may gather together unto God, spending the whole of the seventh day in psalms and hymns and spiritual songs and the study of the divine Scriptures and resting in God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:8
verses.text: For when the law did not exist and there was no divinely-inspired Scripture, the Sabbath was not consecrated to God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:9
verses.text: But when the divinely-inspired Scripture was given by Moses, the Sabbath was consecrated to God in order that on it they, who do not dedicate their whole life to God, and who do not make their desire subservient to the Master as though to a Father, but are like foolish servants, may on that day talk much concerning the exercise of it, and may abstract a small, truly a most insignificant, portion of their life for the service of God, and this from fear of the chastisements and punishments which threaten transgressors.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:10
verses.text: For the law is not made for a righteous man but for the unrighteous.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:11
verses.text: Moses, of a truth, was the first to abide fasting with God for forty days and again for another forty, and thus doubtless to afflict himself with hunger on the Sabbaths although the law forbade self-affliction on the Sabbath.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:12
verses.text: But if they should object that this took place before the law, what will they say about Elias the Thesbite who accomplished a journey of forty days on one meal? For he, by thus afflicting himself on the Sabbaths not only with hunger but with the forty days' journeying, broke the Sabbath: and yet God, Who gave the law, was not wroth with him but shewed Himself to him on Choreb as a reward for his virtue.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:13
verses.text: And what will they say about Daniel? Did he not spend three weeks without food? And again, did not all Israel circumcise the child on the Sabbath, if it happened to be the eighth day after birth? And do they not hold the great fast which the law enjoins if it falls on the Sabbath? And further, do not the priests and the Levites profane the Sabbath in the works of the tabernacle and yet are held blameless? Yea, if an ox should fall into a pit on the Sabbath, he who draws it forth is blameless, while he who neglects to do so is condemned.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:14
verses.text: And did not all the Israelites compass the walls of Jericho bearing the Ark of God for seven days, in which assuredly the Sabbath was included.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:15
verses.text: As I said, therefore, for the purpose of securing leisure to worship God in order that they might, both servant and beast of burden, devote a very small share to Him and be at rest, the observance of the Sabbath was devised for the carnal that were still childish and in the bonds of the elements of the world, and unable to conceive of anything beyond the body and the letter.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:16
verses.text: But when the fulness of the time was come, God sent forth His Only-begotten Son, made of a woman, made under the law, to redeem them that were under the law that we might receive the adoption of sons.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:17
verses.text: For to as many of us as received Him, He gave power to become sons of God, even to them that believe on Him.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:18
verses.text: So that we are no longer servants but sons: no longer under the law but under grace: no longer do we serve God in part from fear, but we are bound to dedicate to Him the whole span of our life, and cause that servant, I mean wrath and desire, to cease from sin and bid it devote itself to the service of God, always directing our whole desire towards God and arming our wrath against the enemies of God: and likewise we hinder that beast of burden, that is the body, from the servitude of sin, and urge it forwards to assist to the uttermost the divine precepts.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:19
verses.text: These are the things which the spiritual law of Christ enjoins on us and those who observe that become superior to the law of Moses.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:20
verses.text: For when that which is perfect is come, then that which is in part shall be done away: and when the covering of the law, that is, the veil, is rent asunder through the crucifixion of the Saviour, and the Spirit shines forth with tongues of fire, the letter shall be done away with, bodily things shall come to an end, the law of servitude shall be fulfilled, and the law of liberty be bestowed on us.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:21
verses.text: Yea we shall celebrate the perfect rest of human nature, I mean the day after the resurrection, on which the Lord Jesus, the Author of Life and our Saviour, shall lead us into the heritage promised to those who serve God in the spirit, a heritage into which He entered Himself as our forerunner after He rose from the dead, and whereon, the gates of Heaven being opened to Him, He took His seat in bodily form at the right hand of the Father, where those who keep the spiritual law shall also come.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:22
verses.text: What belongs to us, therefore, who walk by the spirit and not by the letter, is the complete abandonment of carnal things, the spiritual service and communion with God.
