verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:23
verses.text: For circumcision is the abandonment of carnal pleasure and of whatever is superfluous and unnecessary.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:24
verses.text: For the foreskin is nothing else than the skin which it superfluous to the organ of lust.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:25
verses.text: And, indeed, every pleasure which does not arise from God nor is in God is superfluous to pleasure: and of that the foreskin is the type.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:26
verses.text: The Sabbath, moreover, is the cessation from sin; so that both things happen to be one, and so both together, when observed by those who are spiritual, do not bring about any breach of the law at all.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:27
verses.text: Further, observe that the number seven denotes all the present time, as the most wise Solomon says, to give a portion to seven and also to eight.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:28
verses.text: And David, the divine singer when he composed the eighth psalm, sang of the future restoration after the resurrection from the dead.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 23:29
verses.text: Since the Law, therefore, enjoined that the seventh day should be spent in rest from carnal things and devoted to spiritual things, it was a mystic indication to the true Israelite who had a mind to see God, that he should through all time offer himself to God and rise higher than carnal things.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIV.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:2
verses.text: —Concerning Virginity.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:3
verses.text: Carnal men abuse virginity, and the pleasure-loving bring forward the following verse in proof, Cursed be every one that raiseth not up seed in Israel.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:4
verses.text: But we, made confident by God the Word that was made flesh of the Virgin, answer that virginity was implanted in man's nature from above and in the beginning.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:5
verses.text: For man was formed of virgin soil.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:6
verses.text: From Adam alone was Eve created.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:7
verses.text: In Paradise virginity held sway.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:8
verses.text: Indeed, Divine Scripture tells that both Adam and Eve were naked and were not ashamed.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:9
verses.text: But after their transgression they knew that they were naked, and in their shame they sewed aprons for themselves.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:10
verses.text: And when, after the transgression, Adam heard, dust thou art and unto dust shalt thou return, when death entered into the world by reason of the transgression, then Adam knew Eve his wife, and she conceived and bare seed.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:11
verses.text: So that to prevent the wearing out and destruction of the race by death, marriage was devised that the race of men may be preserved through the procreation of children.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:12
verses.text: But they will perhaps ask, what then is the meaning of "male and female," and "Be fruitful and multiply?" In answer we shall say that "Be fruitful and multiply" does not altogether refer to the multiplying by the marriage connection.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:13
verses.text: For God had power to multiply the race also in different ways, if they kept the precept unbroken to the end.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:14
verses.text: But God, Who knoweth all things before they have existence, knowing in His foreknowledge that they would fall into transgression in the future and be condemned to death, anticipated this and made "male and female," and bade them "be fruitful and multiply".

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:15
verses.text: Let us, then, proceed on our way and see the glories of virginity: and this also includes chastity.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:16
verses.text: Noah when he was commanded to enter the ark and was entrusted with the preservation of the seed of the world received this command, Go in, saith the Lord, thou and thy sons, and thy wife, and thy sons' wives.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:17
verses.text: He separated them from their wives in order that with purity they might escape the flood and that shipwreck of the whole world.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:18
verses.text: After the cessation of the flood, however, He said, Go forth of the ark, thou and thy sons, and thy wife, and thy sons' wives.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:19
verses.text: Lo, again, marriage is granted for the sake of the multiplication of the race.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:20
verses.text: Next, Elias, the fire-breathing charioteer and sojourner in heaven did not embrace celibacy, and yet was not his virtue attested by his super-human ascension? Who closed the heavens? Who raised the dead? Who divided Jordan? Was it not the virginal Elias? And did not Elisha, his disciple, after he had given proof of equal virtue, ask and obtain as an inheritance a double portion of the grace of the Spirit? What of the three youths? Did they not by practising virginity become mightier than fire, their bodies through virginity being made proof against the fire? And was it not Daniel's body that was so hardened by virginity that the wild beasts' teeth could not fasten in it.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:21
verses.text: Did not God, when He wished the Israelites to see Him, bid them purify the body? Did not the priests purify themselves and so approach the temple's shrine and offer victims? And did not the law call chastity the great vow?  The precept of the law, therefore, is to be taken in a more spiritual sense.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:22
verses.text: For there is spiritual seed which is conceived through the love and fear of God in the spiritual womb, travailing and bringing forth the spirit of salvation.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:23
verses.text: And in this sense must be understood this verse: Blessed is he who hath seed in Zion and posterity in Jerusalem.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:24
verses.text: For does it mean that, although he be a whoremonger and a drunkard and an idolater, he is still blessed if only he hath seed in Sion and posterity in Jerusalem? No one in his senses will say this.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:25
verses.text: Virginity is the rule of life among the angels, the property of all incorporeal nature.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:26
verses.text: This we say without speaking ill of marriage: God forbid! (for we know that the Lord blessed marriage by His presence, and we know him who said, Marriage is honourable and the bed undefiled), but knowing that virginity is better than marriage, however good.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:27
verses.text: For among the virtues, equally as among the vices, there are higher and lower grades.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:28
verses.text: We know that all mortals after the first parents of the race are the offspring of marriage.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:29
verses.text: For the first parents were the work of virginity and not of marriage.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:30
verses.text: But celibacy is, as we said, an imitation of the angels.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:31
verses.text: Wherefore virginity is as much more honourable than marriage, as the angel is higher than man.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:32
verses.text: But why do I say angel? Christ Himself is the glory of virginity, who was not only-begotten of the Father without beginning or emission or connection, but also became man in our image, being made flesh for our sakes of the Virgin without connection, and manifesting in Himself the true and perfect virginity.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:33
verses.text: Wherefore, although He did not enjoin that on us by law (for as He said, all men cannot receive this saying), yet in actual fact He taught us that and gave us strength for it.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:34
verses.text: For it is surely clear to every one that virginity now is flourishing among men.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:35
verses.text: Good indeed is the procreation of children enjoined by the law, and good is marriage on account of fornications, for it does away with these, and by lawful intercourse does not permit the madness of desire to be enflamed into unlawful acts.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:36
verses.text: Good is marriage for those who have no continence: but that virginity is better which increases the fruitfulness of the soul and offers to God the seasonable fruit of prayer.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 24:37
verses.text: Marriage is honourable and the bed undefiled, but whoremongers and adulterers God will judge.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 25

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 25:1
verses.text: Chapter XXV.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 25:2
verses.text: —Concerning the Circumcision.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 25:3
verses.text: The Circumcision was given to Abraham before the law, after the blessings, after the promise, as a sign separating him and his offspring and his household from the Gentiles with whom he lived.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 25:4
verses.text: And this is evident, for when the Israelites passed forty years alone by themselves in the desert, having no intercourse with any other race, all that were born in the desert were uncircumcised: but when Joshua led them across Jordan, they were circumcised, and a second law of circumcision was instituted.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 25:5
verses.text: For in Abraham's time the law of circumcision was given, and for the forty years in the desert it fell into abeyance.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 25:6
verses.text: And again for the second time God gave the law of Circumcision to Joshua, after the crossing of Jordan, according as it is written in the book of Joshua, the son of Nun: At that time the Lord said unto Joshua, Make thee knives of stone from the sharp rock, and assemble and circumcise the sons of Israel a second time; and a little later: For the children of Israel walked forty and twoyears in the wilderness of Battaris, till all the people that were men of war, which came out of Egypt, were uncircumcised, because they obeyed not the voice of the Lord: unto whom the Lord sware that He would not shew them the good land, which the Lord swore unto their fathers that He would give them, a land that floweth with milk and honey.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 25:7
verses.text: And their children, whom He raised up in their stead, them Joshua circumcised: for they were uncircumcised, because they had not circumcised them by the way.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 25:8
verses.text: So that the circumcision was a sign, dividing Israel from the Gentiles with whom they dwelt.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 25:9
verses.text: It was, moreover, a figure of baptism.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 25:10
verses.text: For just as the circumcision does not cut off a useful member of the body but only a useless superfluity, so by the holy baptism we are circumcised from sin, and sin clearly is, so to speak, the superfluous part of desire and not useful desire.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 25:11
verses.text: For it is quite impossible that any one should have no desire at all nor ever experience the taste of pleasure.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 25:12
verses.text: But the useless part of pleasure, that is to say, useless desire and pleasure, it is this that is sin from which holy baptism circumcises us, giving us as a token the precious cross on the brow, not to divide us from the Gentiles (for all the nations received baptism and were sealed with the sign of the Cross), but to distinguish in each nation the faithful from the faithless.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 25:13
verses.text: Wherefore, when the truth is revealed, circumcision is a senseless figure and shade.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 25:14
verses.text: So circumcision is now superfluous and contrary to holy baptism.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 25:15
verses.text: For he who is circumcised is a debtor to do the whole law.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 25:16
verses.text: Further, the Lord was circumcised that He might fulfil the law: and He fulfilled the whole law and observed the Sabbath that He might fulfil and establish the law.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 25:17
verses.text: Moreover after He was baptized and the Holy Spirit had appeared to men, descending on Him in the form of a dove, from that time the spiritual service and conduct of life and the Kingdom of Heaven was preached.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVI.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26:2
verses.text: —Concerning the Antichrist.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26:3
verses.text: It should be known that the Antichrist is bound to come.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26:4
verses.text: Every one, therefore, who confesses not that the Son of God came in the flesh and is perfect God and became perfect man, after being God, is Antichrist.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26:5
verses.text: But in a peculiar and special sense he who comes at the consummation of the age is called Antichrist.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26:6
verses.text: First, then, it is requisite that the Gospel should be preached among all nations, as the Lord said, and then he will come to refute the impious Jews.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26:7
verses.text: For the Lord said to them: I am come in My Father's name and ye receive Me not: if another shall come in his own name, him ye will receive.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26:8
verses.text: And the apostle says, Because they received not the love of the truth that they might be saved, for this cause God shall send them a strong delusion that they should believe a lie: that they all might be damned who believed not the truth, but had pleasure in unrighteousness.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26:9
verses.text: The Jews accordingly did not receive the Lord Jesus Christ who was the Son of God and God, but receive the impostor who calls himself God.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26:10
verses.text: For that he will assume the name of God, the angel teaches Daniel, saying these words, Neither shall he regard the God of his fathers.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26:11
verses.text: And the apostle says: Let no man deceive you by any means: for that day shall not come except there come a falling away first, and that man of sin be revealed, the son of perdition: who opposeth and exalteth himself above all that is called God or that is worshipped, so that he sitteth in the temple of God, shewing himself that he is God; in the temple of God he said; not our temple, but the old Jewish temple.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26:12
verses.text: For he will come not to us but to the Jews: not for Christ or the things of Christ: wherefore he is called Antichrist.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26:13
verses.text: First, therefore, it is necessary that the Gospel should be preached among all nations: And then shall that wicked one be revealed, even him whose coming is after the working of Satan with all power and signs and lying wonders, with all deceivableness of unrighteousness in them that perish, whom the Lord shall consume with the word of His mouth and shall destroy with the brightness of His coming.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26:14
verses.text: The devil himself, therefore does not become man in the way that the Lord was made man.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26:15
verses.text: God forbid! but he becomes man as the offspring of fornication and receiveth all the energy of Satan.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26:16
verses.text: For God, foreknowing the strangeness of the choice that he would make, allows the devil to take up his abode in him.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26:17
verses.text: He is, therefore, as we said, the offspring of fornication and is nurtured in secret, and on a sudden he rises up and rebels and assumes rule.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26:18
verses.text: And in the beginning of his rule, or rather tyranny, he assumes the role of sanctity.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26:19
verses.text: But when he becomes master he persecutes the Church of God and displays all his wickedness.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26:20
verses.text: But he will come with signs and lying wonders, fictitious and not real, and he will deceive and lead away from the living God those whose mind rests on an unsound and unstable foundation, so that even the elect shall, if it be possible, be made to stumble.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26:21
verses.text: But Enoch and Elias the Thesbite shall be sent and shall turn the hearts of the fathers to the children, that is, the synagogue to our Lord Jesus Christ and the preaching of the apostles: and they will be destroyed by him.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26:22
verses.text: And the Lord shall come out of heaven, just as the holy apostles beheld Him going into heaven, perfect God and perfect man, with glory and power, and will destroy the man of lawlessness, the son of destruction, with the breath of His mouth.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 26:23
verses.text: Let no one, therefore, look for the Lord to come from earth, but out of Heaven, as He himself has made sure.

chapters.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVII.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:2
verses.text: —Concerning the Resurrection.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:3
verses.text: We believe also in the resurrection of the dead.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:4
verses.text: For there will be in truth, there will be, a resurrection of the dead, and by resurrection we mean resurrection of bodies.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:5
verses.text: For resurrection is the second state of that which has fallen.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:6
verses.text: For the souls are immortal, and hence how can they rise again? For if they define death as the separation of soul and body, resurrection surely is the re-union of soul and body, and the second state of the living creature that has suffered dissolution and downfall.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:7
verses.text: It is, then, this very body, which is corruptible and liable to dissolution, that will rise again incorruptible.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:8
verses.text: For He, who made it in the beginning of the sand of the earth, does not lack the power to raise it up again after it has been dissolved again and returned to the earth from which it was taken, in accordance with the reversal of the Creator's judgment.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:9
verses.text: For if there is no resurrection, let us eat and drink: let us pursue a life of pleasure and enjoyment.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:10
verses.text: If there is no resurrection, wherein do we differ from the irrational brutes? If there is no resurrection, let us hold the wild beasts of the field happy who have a life free from sorrow.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:11
verses.text: If there is no resurrection, neither is there any God nor Providence, but all things are driven and borne along of themselves.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:12
verses.text: For observe how we see most righteous men suffering hunger and injustice and receiving no help in the present life, while sinners and unrighteous men abound in riches and every delight.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:13
verses.text: And who in his senses would take this for the work of a righteous judgment or a wise providence? There must be, therefore, there must be, a resurrection.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:14
verses.text: For God is just and is the rewarder of those who submit patiently to Him.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:15
verses.text: Wherefore if it is the soul alone that engages in the contests of virtue, it is also the soul alone that will receive the crown.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:16
verses.text: And if it were the soul alone that revels in pleasures, it would also be the soul alone that would be justly punished.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:17
verses.text: But since the soul does not pursue either virtue or vice separate from the body, both together will obtain that which is their just due.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:18
verses.text: Nay, the divine Scripture bears witness that there will be a resurrection of the body.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:19
verses.text: God in truth says to Moses after the flood, Even as the green herb have I given you all things.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:20
verses.text: But flesh with the life thereof, which is the blood thereof, shall ye not eat.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:21
verses.text: And surely your blood of your lives will I require; at the hand of every beast will I require it, and at the hand of every man's brother will I require the life of man.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:22
verses.text: Whoso sheddeth man's blood, for his blood his own shall be shed, for in the image of God made I man.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:23
verses.text: How will He require the blood of man at the hand of every beast, unless because the bodies of dead men will rise again? For not for man will the beasts die.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:24
verses.text: And again to Moses, I am the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac and the God of Jacob: God is not the God of the dead (that is, those who are dead and will be no more), but of the living, whose souls indeed live in His hand, but whose bodies will again come to life through the resurrection.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:25
verses.text: And David, sire of the Divine, says to God, Thou takest away their breath, they die and return to their dust.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:26
verses.text: See how he speaks about bodies.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:27
verses.text: Then he subjoins this, Thou sendest forth Thy Spirit, they are created: and Thou renewest the face of the earth.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:28
verses.text: Further Isaiah says: The dead shall rise again, and they that are in the graves shall awake.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:29
verses.text: And it is clear that the souls do not lie in the graves, but the bodies.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:30
verses.text: And again, the blessed Ezekiel says: And it was as I prophesied, and behold a shaking and the bones came together, bone to his bone, each to its own joint: and when I beheld, lo, the sinews came up upon them and the flesh grew and rose up on them and the skin covered them above.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:31
verses.text: And later he teaches how the spirits came back when they were bidden.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:32
verses.text: And divine Daniel also says: And at that time shall Michael stand up, the great prince which standeth for the children of thy people: and there shall be a time of trouble, such trouble as never was since there was a nation on the earth even to that same time.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:33
verses.text: And at that time thy people shall be delivered, every one that shall be found written in the book.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:34
verses.text: And many of them that sleep in the dust of the earth shall awake: some to everlasting life and some to shame and everlasting contempt.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:35
verses.text: And they that be wise shall shine as the brightness of the firmament, and out of the multitude of the just shall shine like stars into the ages and beyond.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:36
verses.text: The words, many of them that sleep in the dust of the earth shall awake, clearly shew that there will be a resurrection of bodies.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:37
verses.text: For no one surely would say that the souls sleep in the dust of the earth.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:38
verses.text: Moreover, even the Lord in the holy Gospels clearly allows that there is a resurrection of the bodies.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:39
verses.text: For they that are in the graves, He says, shall hear His voice and shall come forth: they that have done good unto the resurrection of life, and they that have done evil unto the resurrection of damnation.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:40
verses.text: Now no one in his senses would ever say that the souls are in the graves.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:41
verses.text: But it was not only by word, but also by deed, that the Lord revealed the resurrection of the bodies.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:42
verses.text: First He raised up Lazarus, even after he had been dead four days, and was stinking.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:43
verses.text: For He did not raise the soul without the body, but the body along with the soul: and not another body but the very one that was corrupt.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:44
verses.text: For how could the resurrection of the dead man have been known or believed if it had not been established by his characteristic properties? But it was in fact to make the divinity of His own nature manifest and to confirm the belief in His own and our resurrection, that He raised up Lazarus who was destined once more to die.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:45
verses.text: And the Lord became Himself the first-fruits of the perfect resurrection that is no longer subject to death.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:46
verses.text: Wherefore also the divine Apostle Paul said: If the dead rise not, then is not Christ raised.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:47
verses.text: And if Christ be not raised, our faith is vain: we are yet in our sins.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:48
verses.text: And, Now is Christ risen from the dead and become the first-fruits of them that slept, and the first-born from the dead; and again, For if we believe that Jesus died and rose again, even so them also which sleep in Jesus will God bring with Him.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:49
verses.text: Even so, he said, as Christ rose again.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:50
verses.text: Moreover, that the resurrection of the Lord was the union of uncorrupted body and soul (for it was these that had been divided) is manifest: for He said, Destroy this temple, and in three days I will raise it up.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:51
verses.text: And the holy Gospel is a trustworthy witness that He spoke of His own body.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:52
verses.text: Handle Me and see, the Lord said to His own disciples when they were thinking that they saw a spirit, that it is I Myself, and that I am not changed: for a spirit hath not flesh or bones, as ye see Me have.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:53
verses.text: And when He had said this He shewed them His hands and His side, and stretched them forward for Thomas to touch.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:54
verses.text: Is not this sufficient to establish belief in the resurrection of bodies?  Again the divine apostle says, For this corruptible must put on incorruption, and this mortal must put on immortality.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:55
verses.text: And again: It is sown in corruption, it is raised in incorruption: it is sown in weakness, it is raised in power: it is sown in dishonour, it is raised in glory: it is sown a natural body (that is to say, crass and mortal), it is raised a spiritual body, such as was our Lord's body after the resurrection which passed through closed doors, was unwearying, had no need of food, or sleep, or drink.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:56
verses.text: For they will be, saith the Lord, as the angels of God: there will no longer be marriage nor procreation of children.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:57
verses.text: The divine apostle, in truth, says, For our conversation is in heaven, from whence also we look for the Saviour, the Lord Jesus, Who shall change our vile body that it may be fashioned like unto His glorious body: not meaning change into another form (God forbid!), but rather the change from corruption into incorruption.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:58
verses.text: But some one will say, How are the dead raised up? Oh, what disbelief! Oh, what folly! Will He, Who at His solitary will changed earth into body, Who commanded the little drop of seed to grow in the mother's womb and become in the end this varied and manifold organ of the body, not the rather raise up again at His solitary will that which was and is dissolved? And with what body do they come? Thou fool, if thy hardness will not permit you to believe the words of God, at least believe His works.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:59
verses.text: For that which thou sowest is not quickened except it die.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:60
verses.text: And that which thou sowest, thou sowest not that body that shall be, but bare grain, it may chance of wheat or of some other grain.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:61
verses.text: But God giveth it a body as it hath pleased Him, and to every seed his own body.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:62
verses.text: Behold, therefore, how the seed is buried in the furrows as in tombs.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:63
verses.text: Who is it that giveth them roots and stalk and leaves and ears and the most delicate beards? Is it not the Maker of the universe? Is it not at the bidding of Him Who hath contrived all things? Believe, therefore, in this wise, even that the resurrection of the dead will come to pass at the divine will and sign.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:64
verses.text: For He has power that is able to keep pace with His will.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:65
verses.text: We shall therefore rise again, our souls being once more united with our bodies, now made incorruptible and having put off corruption, and we shall stand beside the awful judgment-seat of Christ: and the devil and his demons and the man that is his, that is the Antichrist and the impious and the sinful, will be given over to everlasting fire: not material fire like our fire, but such fire as God would know.

verses.name: John of Damascus: Exposition of the Orthodox Faith Book IV 27:66
verses.text: But those who have done good will shine forth as the sun with the angels into life eternal, with our Lord Jesus Christ, ever seeing Him and being in His sight and deriving unceasing joy from Him, praising Him with the Father and the Holy Spirit throughout the limitless ages of ages, Amen.
